titleStmt.title: Cooke, Jo., fl. 1614 : : Greenes Tu quoque (1614)

publicationStmt.publisher: Jo. Cooke, fl. 1614 (fl.1612) Greenes Tu quoque, or, The Cittie Gallant. As it hath beene diuers times acted by the Queenes Maiesties Seruants, Written by I. Cooke London Printed ... for Iohn Trundle 1614

sourceDesc.p:
Play details
Greenes Tu quoque. Genre: Comedy. Date first published: 1614. Date first performed: 1611.

editorialDecl.p: The characters are identified by IDREF pointing to information in the following declarations. Will Rash Ballance Lodge Geraldine Longfield Mistress Sweatman Wench. Gartred Francis Spendall Nan Tickleman Pursenet Sir Lionell Gervaise Staines. Bubble Joyce Messenger 2. Messenger Master Blancke Lock-fast Boy Sprinckle a Drawer a Swaggerer Omnes/Ambo Servant Scatter-good Ninnie-Hammer Sargent Sargent2 Fox Prisoner Widow Phillis Basket-Hilt old Geraldine

langUsage.p: The languages (other than English) which occur in the text are identified by idREF which point to the following.

body.stage: A Mercers Shop discouered, Gartred working in it, Spendall walking by the Shop: M Ballance walking ouer the Stage: after him Longfield and Geraldine.

sp.speaker: Francis.
sp.p: What lack you sir? fair stuffs, or velvets?

sp.speaker: Ball.
sp.p: Good morrow Franke.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Good morrow master Balance.

sp.speaker: Gerald.
sp.p: Save you master Long-field.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p:
And you sir, what business draws
you toward this end of the town?

sp.speaker: Gerald.
sp.p:
Faith no great serious affairs, only a stirring
humour to walk, and partly to see the beauties of the City;
but it may be you can instruct me: pray whose shop is
this?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p:
Why it is Will Rashes fathers, a man that you are
well acquainted with.

body.stage: Enter a wench with a basket of linnen

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: As with yourself; and is that his sister?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Marry is it sir.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Pray let us walk, I would behold her better.

sp.speaker: Wench.
sp.p:
Buy some quoifs, handkerchers, or very good
bone-lace Mistress.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: None.

sp.speaker: Wench.
sp.p: Will you buy any handkerchers, sir?

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Yes, have you any fine ones?

sp.speaker: Wench.
sp.p: I will show you choice, please you look sir?

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: How now! what news?

sp.speaker: Wench.
sp.p:
Mistress Tickleman has sent you a Letter, and
expects your company at night, and entreats you to send
her an angel, whether you can come, or whether you can
not.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p:
Sweet rascal! if your love be as earnest as your
protestation, you will meet me this night at Supper, you
know the rendezvous, there will be good company, a noise
of choice Fiddlers, a fine boy with an excellent voice, very
good songs and bawdy; and which is more, I do purpose
myself to be exceeding merry: but if you come not, I
shall pout myself sick, and not cute one bit tonight.
Your continual close friend, Nan Tickle-man.
I pray send me an angel by this bearer, whether
ye can come, or whether ye cannot.
What is the price of these two?

sp.speaker: Wench.
sp.p: Half a crown in truth, sir.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p:
Hold thee, there is an angel, and commend me
to my delight, tell her I will not fail her, though I lose
my freedom by it.

sp.speaker: Wench.
sp.p: I thank you sir; buy any fine handkerchers?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: You are taken sir extremely, what is the object?

sp.speaker: Gerald.
sp.p: She is wondrous fair.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p:
Nay, and your thoughts be on wenching I will
leave you.

sp.speaker: Gerald.
sp.p:
You shall not be so unfriendly, pray assist me;
We will to the shop and cheapen stuffs or satins.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p:
What lack you Gentlemen? fine stuffs, velvets,
or satins? pray come near.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Let me see a good satin.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: You shall sir, what colour?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p:
Faith I am indifferent, what colour most affects
you Lady?

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Without offence (fair creature) I demand it.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p:
Sir, I believe it, but I never did
Tie my affection unto any colour.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p:
But my affection (fairest) is fast tied.
Unto the crimson colour of your cheek.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: You relish too much Courtier, sir.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: What is the price of this?

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Fifteen indeed sir.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: You set a high rate on it, it had need be good.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p:
Good! if you find a better in the town, I will give you
mine for nothing: if you were my own brother, I would put it into
your hands, look upon it, it is close wrought, and has an
excellent glass.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Aye, I see it.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p:
Pray sir come into the next room; I will show you
that of a lower price shall (perhaps) better please you.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p:
This fellow has an excellent tongue, sure he was
brought up in the Exchange.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Will you come in sir?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: No, it is no matter, for I mean to buy none.

sp.speaker: Gerald.
sp.p: Prithee walk in, what you bargain for, I will discharge.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Say so; fall to your work, I will be your chapman.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Why do you say I flatter?

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p:
Why? you do;
And so do all men when they women woo.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p:
Who looks on heaven, and not admires the work?
Who views a well cut Diamond, does not praise
The beauty of the Stone? if these deserve
The name of Excellent, I lack a word
For thee which meritest more,
More than the tongue of man can attribute.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p:
This is pretty Poetry, good fiction this: Sir, I must
leave you.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Leave with me first some comfort.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: What would you crave?

sp.speaker: Gerald.
sp.p: ThaT&H62; which I fear you will not let me have.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: You do not know my bounty; Say what it is.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: No more (fair creature) than a modest kiss.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p:
If I should give you one, would you refrain,
on that condition, never to beg again.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: I dare not grant to that.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p:
Then it seems you have;
Though you get nothing, a delight to crave,
One will not hurt my lip, which you may take,
Not for your love, but for your absence sake. So farewell sir.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p:
O fare thee well (fair regent of my soul)
Never let all sit near thee, unless it come
To purge itself; be as thou ever seemest,
An Angel of thy Sex, born to make happy
The man that shall possess thee for his Bride.

sp.speaker: Spen.
sp.p:
Will you have it for thirteen shillings and six pence?
I will fall to as low a price as I can, because I will buy your custom.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: How now man! what! entranced?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Good sir, have you done?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p:
Yes faith, I think as much as you, and it is just nothing:
where is the wench?

sp.speaker: Gerald.
sp.p: She is here sir, here.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Uds pity! unbutton man, thou wilt stifle her else.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Nay good sir, will you go?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: With all my heart, I stay but for you.

sp.speaker: Spen.
sp.p: Do you hear sir?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: What say?

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Will you take it for thirteen?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Not a penny more than I bid.

sp.speaker: Spend.
Boy.
sp.p: O Franke! shut up shop, shut up shop.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Shut up shop, boy, why?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p:
My Master is come from the Court knighted, and bid
us, for he says he will have the first year of the reign of his Knighthood kept holiday; here he comes.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: God give your worship joy, sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Lion.
sp.p:
O Francke: I have the worship now in the right
kind, the sword of Knighthood sticks still upon my shoulders,
and I feel the blow in my purse, it has cut two leather bags
asunder; but all is one, honour must be purchased: I will give
over my City coat, and betake myself to the Court jacket;
as for trade, I will deal in it no longer, I will seat thee in my
shop, and it shall be thy care to ask men what they lack, my
stock shall be summed up, and I will call thee to an account
for it.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p:
My service sir, never deserved so much,
Nor could I ever hope so large a bounty
Could spring out of your love.

sp.speaker: Sir Lion.
sp.p:
That is all one,
I do love to do things beyond men's hopes,
Tomorrow I remove into the Strand,
There for this quarter dwell, the next at Fulham:
He that hath choice, may shift, the whilst shalt thou
Be master of this house, and rent it free.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: I thank you sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Lion.
sp.p:
Today I will go dine with my Lord Mayor: tomorrow
with the Sheriffs, and next day with the Aldermen, I will
spread the Ensign of my knighthood over the face of the City,
which shall strike as great a terror to my enemies, as ever
Tamberlaine to the Turks.
Come Franke, come in with me, and see the meat,
Upon the which my knighthood first shall eat.

sp.speaker: Staines.
sp.p:
There is a devil has haunted me these three years,
in likeness of an Usurer, a fellow that in all his life never eat
three groat loaves out of his own purse, nor never warmed
him but at other men's fires, never saw a joint of mutton in his
own house these four and twenty years, but always cozened
the poor prisoners, for he always bought his victuals
out of the alms-basket, and yet this rogue now feeds upon
capons which my tenants sent him out of the Country; he is
Landlord forsooth over all my possessions: well, I am spent,
and this rogue has consumed me; I dare not walk abroad to
see my friends, for fear the Sergeants should take a acquaintance
of me: my refuge is Ireland, or Virginia; necessity cries
out, and I will presently to Westchester.

How now! Bubble hast thou packed up all thy things? our parting
time is come: nay prithee do not weep.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Affection sir will burst out.

sp.speaker: Staines.
sp.p:
Thou hast been a faithful servant to me, go to thy
uncle, he will give thee entertainment, tell him upon the stony
rock of his merciless heart my fortunes suffer shipwreck.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p:
I will tell him he is an usuring rascal, and one that
would do the Common-wealth good, if he were hanged.

sp.speaker: Staines.
sp.p:
Which thou hast cause to wish for, thou art his
heir, my affectionate Bubble.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: But Master, wherefore should we be parted?

sp.speaker: Staines.
sp.p: Because my fortunes are desperate, thine are hopeful.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Why but whither do you mean to go Master?

sp.speaker: Staines.
sp.p: Why to Sea.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p:
To sea! Lord bless us, methinks I hear of a tempest
already, but what will you do at Sea?

sp.speaker: Staines.
sp.p: Why as other Gallants do that are spent, turn pirate.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p:
O Master! have the grace of Wapping before your
eyes, remember a high tide, give not your friends cause to wet
their handkerchers: nay Master, I will tell you a better course
than so, you and I will go and rob mine uncle, if we scape,
we will domineer together, if we be taken, we will be hanged
together at Tyburne, that is the warmer gallows of the two.

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.p: By your leave sir, whereabouts dwells one Master. Bubble?

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p:
Do you hear, my friend, do you know Master. Bubble
if you do see him?

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.p: No in truth do I not.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: What is your business with Master Bubble?

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.p: Marry sir, I come with welcome news to him.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Tell it, my friend, I am the man.

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.p: May I be assured sir, that your name is master Bubble?

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p:
I tell thee, honest friend, my name is master Bubble,
Master Bartholomew Bubble.

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.p:
Why then sir, you are heir to a million, for your uncle
the rich usurer is dead.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p:
Pray thee honest friend, go to the next Haberdashers,
and bid him send me a new melancholy hat, and take thou
that for thy labour.

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.p: I will sir.

body.stage: Enter another Messenger hastily, and knockes.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Um, um, um.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p:
I would the news were true; see how my little Bubble
is blown up with it!

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Do you hear, my friend, for what do you knock there?

sp.speaker: 2. Mes.
sp.p:
Marry sir, I would speak with the worshipful
Master Bubble.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p:
The worshipful! and what would you do with the
worshipful Master Bubble? I am the man.

sp.speaker: 2. Mes.
sp.p:
I cry your worship mercy then, Master Thong the
Belt-maker sent me to your worship, to give you notice, that
your uncle is dead, and that you are his only heir.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p:
Thy news is good, and I have looked for it long,
Thanks unto thee, my friend, and goodman Thong.

sp.speaker: Staines.
sp.p:
Certainly, this news is true: for see another, by
this light his Scrivener! now Master. Blank, whither away so fast?

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: Master Staines, God save you, where is your man?

sp.speaker: Staines.
sp.p: Why look you sir, do you not see him?

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p:
God save the right worshipful master Bubble; I bring
you heavy news with a light heart.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: What are you?

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: I am your worships poor Scrivener.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: He is an honest man it seems, for he has both his ears.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p:
I am one that your worships uncle committed some
trust in for the putting out of his money, and I hope I shall have
the putting out of yours.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p:
The putting out of mine! would you have the putting
out of money?

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: Yea sir.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: No sir, I am old enough to put out my own money.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: I have writings of your worships.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p:
As thou lovest thy profit, hold thy tongue, thou and I
will confer.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p:
Do you hear, my friend, can you tell me when, and
how my uncle died?

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: Yes sir, he died this morning, and he was killed by a Butcher?

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: How! by a Butcher?

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p:
Yes indeed sir, for going this morning into the Market,
to cheapen meat, he fell down stark dead, because a
Butcher asked him four shillings for a shoulder of Mutton.

sp.speaker: Bu.
sp.p: How stark dead! and could not aqua vitæ fetch him again?

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p:
No sir, nor Rosa solis neither, and yet there was trial
made of both.

sp.speaker: Bu.
sp.p: I shall love aqua vitæ and rosa solis the better while I live.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p:
Will it please your worship to accept of my poor service,
you know my case is desperate, I beseech you that I may
feed upon your bread, though it be of the brownest, and drink of
your drink though it be of the smallest, for I am humble in body,
and dejected in mind, and will do your worship as good service
for forty shillings a year, as another shall for three. pounds.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p:
I will not stand with you for such a matter, because you
have been my master, but otherwise, I will entertain no man
without some Knights or Ladies Letter for their behaviour,
Geruase I take it is your christen name.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: Yes if it please your worship.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p:
Well Geruase, be a good servant, and you shall find
me a dutiful master: and because you have been a Gentleman,
I will entertain you for my Tutor in behaviour; Conduct
me to my palace.

body.stage: Enter Geraldine as in his study reading.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p:
As little children love to play with fire,
And will not leave till they themselves do burn,
So did I fondly dally with Desire:
Until Love's flames grew hot, I could not turn,
Nor well avoid; but sigh and sob, and mourn
As children do, when as they feel the pain,
Till tender mother kiss them whole again.
Fie, what unsavoury stuff is this? but she,
Whose mature judgment can distinguish things,
Will thus conceit; tales that are harshest told,
Have smoothest meanings, and to speak are bold:
It is the first-born Sonnet of my brain,
We sucked a white leaf from my black-lipped pen
So sad employment,
Yet the dry paper drinks it up as deep,
As if it flowed from Petrarkes cunning Quill.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p:
How now! what have we here, a Sonnet and a Satire
coupled together like my Ladies Dog and her Monkey; As
little children etcetera.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p:
Prithee away, by the deepest oath that can be sworn,
thou shalt not read it, by our friendship I conjure thee, prithee let go.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p:
Now in the name of Cupid, what wantest thou, a pigeon,
a dove, a mate, a turtle, dost love fowl, ha?
O no, she is fairer thrice than is the Queen,
Whom beauteous Venus called is by name, prithee let me
know what she is thou lovest, that I may shun her, if I should
chance to meet her.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Why I will tell you sir what she is, if you do not know.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: No not I, I protest.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Why it is your sister.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: How! my sister?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Yes, your eldest sister.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p:
Now God bless the man, he had better choose a wench
that has been born and bred in an alley, her tongue is a perpetual
motion, Thought is not so swift as it is; and for pride, the
woman that had her Ruff poked by the devil, is but a Puritan
to her, thou couldst never have fastened thy affection on a
worse subject, she will flout faster than a court-waiting woman
in progress, any man that comes in the way of honesty does
she set her mark upon, that is, a villainous least; for she is a
kind of Poetess, and will make Ballads upon the calves of
your legs: I prithee let her alone; she will never make a good
wife for any man unless it be a Leather dresser; for perhaps
he, in time, may turn her.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p:
Thou hast a Privilege to utter this,
But by my life my own blood could not scape
A chastisement for thus profaning her,
Whose virtues sits above men's calumnies,
Had mine own brother spoke thus liberally,
My fury should have taught him better manners.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: No more words as you fear a challenge.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p:
I may tell thee in thine ear, I am glad to hear what
I do; I pray God send her no worse husband, nor he no worse
wife: do you hear love, will you take your Cloak and Rapier,
and walk abroad into some wholesome air? I do much fear
thy infection, good counsel I see will do no good on thee, but
pursue the end, and to thy thoughts, I will prove a faithful friend.

body.stage: Enter Spendall, Nan Tickleman, Sweatman, Pursenet, and a Drawer.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p:
Here is a spacious room to walk in, sirrah set down
the candle, and fetch us up a quart of Ipocras, and so we will part.

sp.speaker: Sweat.
sp.p:
Nay faith Son, we will have a pottle, let us never be
covetous in our young days.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: A pottle sirrah, do you hear?

sp.speaker: Dra.
sp.p: Yes sir, you shall.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: How now Wench! how dost?

sp.speaker: Tickle.
sp.p:
Faith I am somewhat sick, yet I should be well enough
if I had a new gown.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p:
Why here is my hand, within these three days thou
shalt have one.

sp.speaker: Sweat.
sp.p:
And will you (son) remember me for a new forepart,
by my troth, my old one is worn so bare, I am ashamed
anybody should see it.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Why, did I ever fail of my promise?

sp.speaker: Sweat.
sp.p: No in sincerity didst thou not,

sp.speaker: Dra.
sp.p: Here is a cup of rich Ipocras.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p:
Here sister, mother, and master Pursnet; nay good
sir, be not so dejected, for by this wine, tomorrow I will send
you stuff for a new suite, and as much as shall line you a cloak
clean through.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: I thank you, and shall study to deserve.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p:
Here boy, fill, and hang that curmudgeon that is good
for no body but himself.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p:
Heroically spoken by this Candle, it is pity thou wert
not made a Lord.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p:
A Lord! by this Light I do not think but to be
Lord Mayor of London before I die, and have three Pageants
carried before me, besides a Ship and an Unicorn; prentices
may pray for that time, for whensoever it happens, I will
make another Shrove tuesday for them.

sp.speaker: Dra.
sp.p: Young master Rash has sent you a quart of Maligoe.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Master. Rash! zownds how does he know I am here?

sp.speaker: Dra.
sp.p: Nay, I know not sir.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p:
Know not! it comes through you and your rascally
glib-tongued companions, it is my Masters son, a fine gentleman
he is, and a boon companion, I must go see him.

sp.speaker: Sweat.
sp.p:
Boy, fill us a cup of your maligo, we will drink to Master.
Spendall in his absence, there is not a finer spirit of a Citizen
within the walls, here master Pursnet you shall pledge him.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p:
I will not refuse it were it puddle: by Styx he is a bountiful
Gentleman, and I shall report him so: here Master. Tickleman,
shall I charge you?

sp.speaker: Tickle.
sp.p:
Do your worst Sergeant, I will pledge my young
Spendall a whole sea, as they say, fa la la la la, would the Music
were here again, I do begin to be wanton, Ipocras
sirrah, and a dry biscuit; here bawd, a carouse.

sp.speaker: Sweat.
sp.p:
Bawd! I saith you begin to grow light in the head, I
pray, no more such words, for if you do, I shall grow into distempers.

sp.speaker: Tickle.
sp.p:
Distempers! hang your distempers, be angry with
me if thou durst, I pray, who seeds you, but I? who keeps
the feather-beds from the Brokers, but I? it is not your sausage
face, thick clotted cream rampallion at home, that
snuffles in the nose like a decayed Bagpipe.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p:
Nay, sweet Mistress Tickleman, be concordant, reverence
Antiquity.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p:
Save you, sweet creatures of beauty, save you:
How now old Beelzebub, how dost thou?

sp.speaker: Sweat.
sp.p: Beelzebub! Beelzebub in thy face.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p:
Nay, good words Mistress Sweatman, he is a young
Gallant; you must not weigh what he says.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p:
I would my lamentable complaining Lover had
been here, here had been a Supersede as for his melancholy,
and i'faith Francke I am glad my father has turned over
his shop to thee, I hope I, or any friend of mine, shall have so
much credit with thee, as to stand in thy books for a suite of
Satin.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p:
For a whole piece, if you please, any friend of yours
shall command me to the last remnant.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: Why God a mercy Francke, what, shall us to dice?

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p:
Dice or drink, here is forty crowns, as long as
that will last, anything.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: Why there spoke a jingling Boy.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p:
A pox of money, it is but rubbish, and he that hoards
it up, is but a Scavenger: if there be cards in the house, let us go
to Primero.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p:
Primero! why I thought thou hadst not been so much
gamester as to play at it.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p:
Gamester (to say truth) I am none, but what is it I
will not be in good company? I will fit myself to all humours,
I will game with a Gamester, drink with a drunkard, be civil
with a citizen, fight with a swaggerer, and drab with a
whoremaster.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: An excellent humour i'faith.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Zownds what have we here?

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: A land Porpoise, I think.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p:
This is no angry, nor no roaring boy, but a blustering
boy; now Eolus defend us, what puffs are these?

sp.speaker: Swag.
sp.p: I do smell a whore.

sp.speaker: Dra.
sp.p:
O Gentlemen, give him good words, he is one of the
roaring boys.

sp.speaker: Swag.
sp.p: Rogue.

sp.speaker: Dra.
sp.p: Here sir.

sp.speaker: Swag.
sp.p:
Take my cloak, I must unbuckle, my pickled oysters
work; puff, puff.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Puff, puff,

sp.speaker: Swag.
sp.p: Dost thou retort, in opposition stand.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p:
Out you swaggering Rogue, Zownds I will kick him
out of the room.

sp.speaker: Tickle.
sp.p: Out alas! their naked tools are out,

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Fear not (sweet heart;) come along with me.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p:
Thrice happy days they were, and too soon gone,
When as the heart was coupled with the tongue,
And no deceitful flattery or guile:
Hung on the Lover's tear-commixed smile:
Could women learn but that imperiousness,
By which men use to flint our happiness,
When they have purchased us for to be theirs,
By customary sighs and forced tears,
To give us bits of kindness lest we faint,
But no abundance, that we ever want,
And still are begging; which too well they know
Endears affection, and doth make it grow:
Had we these sleights, how happy were we then,
That we might glory over love-sick men?
But Arts we know not, nor have any skill,
To fain a sour look to a pleasing will,
Nor couch a secret love in show of hate:
But if we like, must be compassionate;
Yet I will strive to bridle and conceal,
The hid affection which my heart doth feel.

sp.speaker: Ioyce.
sp.p:
Now the boy with the Bird-bolt be praised: nay faith
sister forward, it was an excellent passion, come let us hear,
what is he? if he be a proper man, and have a black eye, a
smooth chin, and a curled pate, take him wench, if my father
will not consent, run away with him, I will help to convey
you.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: You talk strangely sister.

sp.speaker: Ioyce.
sp.p:
Sister, sister, dissemble not with me, though you do
mean to dissemble with your lover, though you have protested
to conceal your affection; by this tongue you shall not,
for I will discover all as soon as I know the Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: Discover, what will you discover?

sp.speaker: Ioyce.
sp.p:
Marry, enough I will warrant thee, first and foremost, I will
tell him thou readest love-passions in print, and speakest every
morning without book to thy looking-glass; next, that thou
never sleep'st, till an hour after the Bell man; that as soon as
thou art asleep, thou art in a dream, and in a dream thou art
the kindest and comfortablest bed-fellow for kissings and
embracings; by this hand, I cannot rest for thee, but our father. -

sp.speaker: Lyonell.
sp.p:
How now! what are you two consulting on, on
husbands? you think you lose time I am sure, but hold
your own a little Girls, it shall not be long ere I will provide
for you: and for you Gartred, I have bethought myself already,
Whirl pit the usurer is late deceased,
A man of unknown wealth, which he has left
Unto a provident kinsman as I hear,
That was once servant to that unthrift Straines.
A prudent Gentleman they say he is,
And (as I take it) called master Bubble.

sp.speaker: Lyonell
sp.p: Yes nimble-chaps, what say you to that?

sp.speaker: Ioyce.
sp.p:
Nothing, but that I wish his Christen name were
Water.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p:
Sir, I am at your disposing, but my mind
Stands not as yet towards marriage,
Were you so pleased I would a little longer
Enjoy the quiet of a single bed.

sp.speaker: Lyonell.
sp.p:
Here is the right trick of them all, let a man
Be motioned to vm, they could be content
To lead a single life forsooth, when the harlotries
Do pine and run into diseases,
Eat chalk and oatmeal, cry and creep in corners,
Which are manifest tokens of their longings,
And yet they will dissemble. But Gartred,
As you do owe me reverence, and will pay it,
Prepare yourself to like this Gentleman,
Who can maintain thee in thy choice of Gowns,
Of tires, of servants, and of costly Jewels;
Nay for a need, out of his easy nature,
Mayst draw him to the keeping of a Coach
For Country, and Caroche for London,
Indeed what mightst thou not.

sp.speaker: Seruant.
sp.p:
Sir, here is one come from Master Bubble, to invite
you to the funeral of his uncle.

sp.speaker: Lyonell
sp.p:
Thank the Messenger, and make him drink,
Tell him I will not fail to wait the coarse,
Yet stay, I will go talk with him myself:
Gartred, think upon what I have told you,
And let me ere it be long receive your answer.

sp.speaker: Ioyce.
sp.p: Sister, sister.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: What say you sister?

sp.speaker: Ioyce.
sp.p: Shall I provide a Cord?

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: A Cord! what to do?

sp.speaker: Ioyce.
sp.p:
Why to let thee out at the window; do not I know
that thou wilt run away with the Gentleman, for whom you
made the passion, rather than endure this same Bubble, that my
father talks of, it were good you would let me be of your
counsel, lest I break the neck of your plot.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p:
Sister, know I love thee,
And I will not think a thought thou shalt not know;
I love a Gentleman that answers me,
In all the rites of love as faithfully,
Has wooed me oft with Sonnets, and with tears,
Yet I seem still to slight him. Experience tells,
The Jewel that is enjoyed is not esteemed,
Things hardly got, are always highest deemed.

sp.speaker: Ioyce.
sp.p:
You say well sister, but it is not good to linger out too
long, continuance of time will take away any man's stomach
in the world; I hope the next time that he comes to you, I shall
see him.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: You shall.

sp.speaker: Ioyce.
sp.p:
Why go to then, you shall have my opinion of him,
if he deserve thee, thou shalt delay him no longer; for if you
can not find in your heart to tell him you love him, I will sigh it
out for you; come, we little creatures must help one another.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p:
How cheerfully things look in this place,
It is always Spring-time here, such is the grace
And potency of her who has the bliss,
To make it still Elisium where she is:
Nor doth the King of flames in his golden fires,
After a tempest answer men's desires,
When as he casts his comfortable beams,
Over the flowery fields and silver streams,
As her illustrate Beauty strikes in me,
And wraps my soul up to felicity.

sp.speaker: Ioyce.
sp.p: Do you hear sir?

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: Why sister, what will you do?

sp.speaker: Ioyce.
sp.p:
By my maidenhead, an oath which I never took in
vain, either go down and comfort him, or I will call him up,
and disclose all: What, will you have no mercy? but let a proper
man, that might spend the spirit of his youth upon
yourself, fall into a consumption, for shame sister.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p:
You are the strangest creature, what would you have me
do?

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p:
Marry, I would have you go to him, take him by the
hand, and grip him, say you are welcome, I love you with all my
heart, you are the man must do the feat, and take him about
the neck, and kiss upon the bargain.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p:
Fie how you talk, it is mere immodesty,
The commonest strumpet would not do so much.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p:
Marry the better, for such as are honest,
Should still do what the common strumpet will not:
Speak, will you do it?

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: I will lose his company for ever first.

sp.speaker: Ioyce.
sp.p:
Do you hear sir? here is a Gentlewoman would
speak with you.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: Why sister, pray sister.

sp.speaker: Ioyce.
sp.p:
One that loves you with all her heart, yet is ashamed
to confess it.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p:
Good sister hold your tongue, I will go down to
him.

sp.speaker: Ioyce.
sp.p:
Do not jest with me, for by this hand I will either
get him up, or go down myself, and read the whole History
of your love to him.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: If you will forbear to call, I will go down.

sp.speaker: Ioyce.
sp.p:
Let me see your back then, and hear you? do not
use him scurvily you were best; unset all your tyrannical looks,
and bid him lovingly welcome, or as I live, I will stretch out my
voice again; uds foot, I must take some pains I see, or we
shall never have this gear cotton: but to say truth, the fault is
in my melancholy Monsieur, for if he had but half so much
spirit, as he has flesh, he might have boarded her by this. But
see, yonder she marches; now a passion of his side of half an
hour long, his hat is off already, as if he were begging one
poor penny-worth of kindness.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p:
Shall I presume (fair Mistress) on your hand to lay my
unworthy lip?

sp.speaker: Ioyce.
sp.p:
Fie upon him, I am ashamed to hear him, you shall
have a Country fellow at a Maypole, go better to his work:
he had need to be constant, for he is able to spoil as many
Maids as he shall fall in love withal.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p:
Sir, you profess love unto me, let me entreat you it
may appear but in some small request.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Let me know it (Lady) and I shall soon effect it.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p:
But for this present to forbear this place,
Because my father is expected here.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: I am gone Lady.

sp.speaker: Ioyce.
sp.p: Do you hear sir?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Did you call?

sp.speaker: Ioyce.
sp.p: Look up to the window.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: What say you Gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: Nay pray sir go, it is my sister calls to hasten you.

sp.speaker: Ioyce.
sp.p: I call to speak with you, pray stay a little.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: The Gentlewoman has something to say to me.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p:
She has nothing, I do conjure you, as you love me,
stay not.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: The power of Magic cannot fasten me, I am gone.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p:
Good sir, look back no more, what voice ever call you,
Imagine, going from me, you were coming,
And use the same speed, as you love my safety.
Wild witted sister, I have prevented you,
I will not have my love yet opened to him,
By how much longer it is ere it be known,
By so much dearer it will be when it is purchased:
But I must use my strength to stop her journey,
For she will after him: and see, she comes;
Nay sister, you are at furthest.

sp.speaker: Ioyce.
sp.p:
Let me go you were best, for if you wrestle with me
I shall throw you, passion, come back, fool, lover, turn again,
and kiss your belly full;
For here she is will stand you, do your worst:
Will you let me go?

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: Yes, if you will stay.

sp.speaker: Ioyce.
sp.p:
If I stir a foot, hang me, you shall come together
of yourselves, and be naught, do what you will, for if ever I
trouble myself again, let me want help
in such a case when I need.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: Nay but prithee sister be not angry.

sp.speaker: Ioyce.
sp.p:
I will be angry, vdsfoot, I cannot endure such foolery,
I, two bashful fools that would couple together, and yet
have not the faces.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: Nay prithee sweet sister.

sp.speaker: Ioyce.
sp.p:
Come, come, let me go, birds that want the use of
reason and speech, can couple together in one day, and yet you
that have both, cannot conclude in twenty.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: Why what good would it do you to tell him?

sp.speaker: Ioyce.
sp.p:
Do not talk to me, for I am deaf to anything you
say, go weep and cry.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: Nay but sister.

body.stage: Enter Staines, and a Drawer with wine.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p:
Drawer, bid them make haste at home,
Tell them they are coming from church.

sp.speaker: Dra.
sp.p: I will sir.

body.stage: Enter Bubble, sir Lionell, and Long-field and Sprinckle.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p:
That I should live to be a serving-man, a fellow which
scalds his mouth with another man's porridge, brings up meat
for other men's bellies, and carries away the bones for his own,
changes his clean trench or for a foul one, and is glad of it,
and yet did I never live so merry a life, when I was my masters
master, as now I do, being man to my man, and I will stand
to it for all my former speeches, a serving-man lives a better
life than his Master, and thus I prove it; the saying is, The
nearer the bone the sweeter the flesh: then must the serving-man
needs eat the sweeter flesh, for he always picks the
bones. And again the Proverb says, The deeper the sweeter:
There has the serving-man the vantage again, for he drinks
still in the bottom of the pot, he fills his belly, and never
asks what is to pay? wears broad-cloth, and yet dares walk
Watling street without any fear of his Draper: and for his
clothes, they are according to the season, in the Summer he
is apparelled (for the most part) like the heavens, in blue, in
the winter, like the earth, in freeze.
But see, I am prevented in my Encomium,
I could have maintained this theme these two hours.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p:
Well, God rest his soul, he is gone, and we must all
follow him

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Aye, aye, he is gone sir Lionell, he is gone.

sp.speaker: Lyonell.
sp.p:
Why thou he be gone, what then? it is not you that
can fetch him again, with all your cunning, it must be your
comfort, that he died well.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p:
Truly and so it is, I would to God I had even another
uncle that would die no worse; surely I shall weep again,
if I should find my handkercher.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: How now! what, are these onions?

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p:
Aye, aye, sir Lyonell, they are my onions, I thought to have
had them roasted this morning for my cold: Geruase you have
not wept today, pray take your onions Gentlemen, the remembrance
of death is sharpe, therefore there is a banquet
within to sweeten your conceits: I pray walk in Gentlemen,
walk you in, you know I must needs be melancholy, and
keep my Chamber, Geruase, usher them into the banquet.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: I shall sir, please you sir Lyonell.

sp.speaker: Lyonell
sp.p:
Well Master Bubble, we will go in and taste of your
bounty.
In the mean time, you must be of good cheer.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p:
If grief take not away my stomach,
I will have good cheer I warrant you Sprinkle.

sp.speaker: Sprin.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Had the women puddings to their dole?

sp.speaker: Sprin.
sp.p: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: And how did they take them?

sp.speaker: Sprin.
sp.p: Why with their hands, how should they take them?

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p:
O thou Hercules of ignorance! I mean, how were they
satisfied?

sp.speaker: Sprin.
sp.p:
By my troth sir, but so so, and yet some of them had
two.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p:
O insatiable women! whom two puddings would not
satisfy, but vanish Sprinkle; bid your fellow Geruase come
hither:
And off my mourning robes, grief to the grave,
For I have gold, and therefore will be brave:
In silks I will rattle it of every colour,
And when I go by water, scorn a Sculler,
In black carnation velvet I will cloak me,
And when men bid God save me, Cry Tu quoque:
It is needful a Gentleman should speak Latin sometimes, is it not Geruase?

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p:
O very graceful sir, your most accomplished Gentlemen
are known by it.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p:
Why then will I make use of that little I have,
Upon times and occasions, here Geruase, take this bag,
And run presently to the Mercers, buy me seven ells of horse
flesh coloured taffeta, nine yards of yellow satin, and eight
yards of orange tawny velvet; then run to the Tailors, the
Haberdashers, the Sempsters, the Cutlers, the Perfumers, and
to all trades whatsoever that belong to the making up of a Gentleman;
and amongst the rest, let not the Barber be forgotten:
and look that he be an excellent fellow, and one that
can snack his fingers with dexterity.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: I shall sit you sir.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p:
Do so good Geruase, it is time my beard were corrected,
for it is grown so saucy, as it begins to play with
my nose.

sp.speaker: Staines.
sp.p: Your nose sir must endure it: for it is in part the fashion.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p:
Is it in fashion? why then my nose shall endure it, let
it tickle his worst.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p:
Why now you are in the right sir, if you will be a true Gallant,
you must bear things resolute, as this sir, if you be at an
Ordinary, and chance to lose your money at play, you must
not fret and fume, tear cards, and fling away dice, as your
ignorant gamester, or country-Gentleman does, but you must
put on a calm temperate action, with a kind of careless smile,
in contempt of Fortune, as not being able with all her engines
to batter down one piece of your estate, that your means may
be thought invincible, never tell your money, nor what you
have won, nor what you have lost: if a question be made:
your answer must be, what I have lost, I have lost, what I have
won, I have won, a close heart and free hand, makes a
man admired, a testern or a shilling to a servant that brings
you a glass of beer, binds his hands to his lips, you shall
have more service of him, than his Master, he will be more
humble to you, than a Cheater before a Magistrate.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p:
Geruase, give me thy hand, I think thou hast more
wit than I that am thy Master, and for this Speech only, I do
here create thee my steward: I do long methinks to be at an
Ordinary, to smile at Fortune, and to be bountiful: Geruase about
your business good Geruase, whilst I go and meditate
upon a Gentleman-like behaviour, I have an excellent gate
already Geruase, have I not?

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: Hercules himself sir, had never a better gate.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p:
But dispatch Geruase, the satin and the velvet must be
thought upon, and the Tu quoque must not be forgotten: for
whensoever I give Arms, that shall be my Motto.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p:
What a fortune had I thrown upon me, when I preferred
myself into this fellows service! indeed I serve myself,
and not him, for this Gold here is mine own truly
purchased: he has credit, and shall run in the books for it, I will
carry things so cunningly, that he shall not be able to look into
my actions, my mortgage I have already got into my hands:
the rent he shall enjoy a while, till his riot constrain him to
sell it, which I will purchase with his own money, I must
cheat a little, I have been cheated upon, therefore I hope
the world will a little the better excuse me, what his uncle
craftily got from me, I will knavishly recover of him, to come
by it, I must vary shapes, and my first shift shall be in satin:
Proteus propitious be to my disguise,
And I shall prosper in my enterprise.

body.stage: Enter Spendall, Pursenet, and a boy with Rackets.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: A Rubber sirrah.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: You shall sir.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p:
And bid those two men you said would speak with
me, come in.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: I will sir.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Did I not play this Set well?

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p:
Excellent well by Phaeton, by Erebus, it went as if it
had cut the Line.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: God bless you sir.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Master Blank! welcome.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: Here is the Gentleman's man sir has brought the money.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Wilt please you tell sir?

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Have you the Bond ready master Blank?

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p:
It is well, Pursenet, help to tell - ten eleven twelve.
What time have you given?

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: The thirteenth of the next Month.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: It is well, here is light gold.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: It will be the less troublesome to carry.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: You say well sir, how much hast thou told?

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: In gold and silver here is twenty pounds.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: It is right Master. Spendall, I will warrant you.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p:
I will take your warrant sir, and tell no further, come
let me see the Condition of this Obligation.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p:
A man may win from him that cares not for it,
This royal Cæsar doth regard no Cash,
Has thrown away as much in Ducks and Drakes,
As would have bought some 50000 Capons.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: It is very well; so, lend me your pen.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p:
This is the Captain of brave Citizens,
The Agamemnon of all merry Greeks,
A Stukely or a Sherley for his spirit,
Bounty and Royalty to men at arms.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: You give this as your deed.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Marry do I sir.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: Pleaseth this Gentleman to be a witness.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Yes Marry shall he, Pursenet, your hand.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: My hand is at thy service, Noble Brutus.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: There is for your kindness master Blank.

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: I thank you sir.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: For your pains.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: I will take my leave of you.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: What, must you be gone too, master Blank?

sp.speaker: Bla.
sp.p: Yes indeed sir, I must to the Exchange.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p:
Farewell to both, Pursenet,
Take that twenty pounds, and give it mistress Sweatman,
Bid her pay her Landlord and Apothecary,
And let her Butcher and her Baker stay,
They are honest men, and I will take order with them.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: The Butcher and the Baker then shall stay.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: They must till I am some what stronger pursed.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: If this be all, I have my errand perfect.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Here sirrah, here is for balls, there is for yourself.

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p: I thank your worship.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Commend me to your mistress.

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p:
I will sir; in good faith it is the liberalest Gentleman
that comes into our Court, why he cares no more for a shilling
than I do for a box on the ear, God bless him.

body.stage: Enter Staines Gallant, Long-field and a Seruant.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: Sirrah, what a clock is it?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Past ten sir.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: Here will not be a Gallant seen this hour.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p:
Within this quarter sir, and less, they meet here as
soon as at any Ordinary in the town.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: Hast any Tobacco?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: Fill.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p:
Why thou reportest miracles, things not to be believed:
I protest to thee, hadst thou not unripped thyself to me,
I should never have known thee.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p:
I tell you true sir, I was so far gone, that desperation
knocked at mine elbow, and whispered news to me out
of Barbarie.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p:
Well, I am glad so good an occasion staid thee at home,
And mayst thou prosper in thy project, and go on,
With best success of thy invention.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p:
False dice say Amen, for that is my induction,
I do mean to cheat today without respect of persons:
When sawest thou Will Rash?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: This morning at his Chamber, he will be here.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p:
Why then do thou give him my name and character,
for my aim is wholly at my worshipful Master.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p:
Nay thou shalt take another into him, one that laughs
out his life in this Ordinary, thanks any man that wins his
money; all the while his money is loosing, he swears by the
cross of this silver, and when it is gone, he changeth it to the
hilts of his sword.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: He will be an excellent coach-horse for my captain.

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p: Save you Gallants, save you.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: How think ye now? have I not carved him out to you?

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: Thou hast lighted me into his heart, I see him thoroughly.

sp.speaker: Nin.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p:
Take my cloak and rapier also: I think it be early
Gentlemen, what time do you take it to be?

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: Inclining to eleven sir.

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p:
Inclining! a good word; I would it were inclining
to twelve, for by my stomach it should be high Noon: but
what shall we do Gallants? shall we to cards, till our Company
come?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Please you sir.

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p:
Harry fetch sir Cards, methinks it is an unseemly
fight to see Gentlemen stand idle, please you to impart your
smoke.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Very willingly sir.

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p: In good faith a pipe of excellent vapour.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: The best the house yields.

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p:
Had you it in the house? I had thought it had been
your own: it is not so good now as I took it to be: Come
Gentlemen, what is your game?

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: Why Gleek, that is your only game.

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p:
Gleek let it be, for I am persuaded I shall gleek
some of you; cut sir.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: What play we, twelve pence gleek.

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p:
Twelve pence, a crown; uds foot I will not spoil
my memory for twelve pence.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: Honour.

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p: What is it, Hearts?

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: The King, what say you?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: You must speak sir.

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p: Why I bid thirteen.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: Fourteen.

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p: Fifteen.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: Sixteen.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Sixteen, seventeen.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: You shall have it for me.

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p: Eighteen.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Take it to you sir.

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p: Uds'lid I will not be out-braved.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: I vie it.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: I will none of it.

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p: Nor I.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: Give me a mournaval of aces, and a gleek of queens.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: And me a gleek of knaues.

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p: Uds'lid, I am gleeked this time.

sp.speaker: Stay.
sp.p: Play.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: Equal fortunes befall you Gallants.

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p: Will Rash, well, I pray see what a vile game I have

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: What is your game, Gleek?

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p:
Yes faith, Gleek, and I have not one Court card, but
the knave of Clubs.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p:
Thou hast a wild hand indeed: thy small cards show
like a troupe of rebels, and the knave of Clubs their chief
Leader.

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p:
And so they do as God save me, by the cross of this
silver he says true.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: Pray, play sir:

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Honour.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: How go the stocks Gentlemen, what is won or lost?

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: This is the first game.

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p:
Yes this is the first game, but by the cross of this silver
here is all of five pounds.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Good day to you Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: Francke, welcome by this hand, how dost lad?

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: And how does thy wench i'faith.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p:
Why fat and plump
Like thy geldings: thou givest them both good provender
It seems, go to, thou art one of the maddest wags,
Of a Citizen in the town, the whole company talks of thee
already.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p:
Talk, why let them talk, vdsfoot I pay scot and lot,
and all manner of duties else, as well as the best of them: it may
be they understand I keep a whore, a horse, and a kennel of
hounds, what is that to them? no man's purse opens for it but
mine own; and so long, my hounds shall eat flesh, my horse
bread, and my whore wear velvet.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: Why there spoke a courageous Boy.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p:
Vdsfoote, shall I be confined all the days of my life
to walk under a pent-house? no, I will take my pleasure whiles
my youth affords it.

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p:
By the cross of these hilts, I will never play at Gleek
again, whilst I have a nose on my face,
I smell the knavery of the game.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Why what is the matter? who has lost?

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p:
Marry that have I, by the hilts of my sword, I have
lost forty crowns, in as small time almost, as while a man might
tell it.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p:
Change your Game for dice,
We are a full number for Nouum.

sp.speaker: Scatt.
sp.p:
With all my heart, where is Master. Ambush the Broker
Ninni-hammer?

sp.speaker: Nin.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p:
Go to Master. Ambush, and bid him send me twenty marks
upon this Diamond.

sp.speaker: Nin.
sp.p: I will sir.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Look you (to make us the merrier) who comes here.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: A fresh Gamester, Master. Bubble, God save you.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Tu quoque sir.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: God save you Master Bubble.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: Save you sir.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Good master Bubleb

sp.speaker: Scatt.
sp.p: Is your name Master Bubble?

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Master Bubble is my name, sir.

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p: God save you sir.

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p: I would be better acquainted with you.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: And I with you.

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p: Pray let us salute again.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: With all my heart sir.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Behold yonder the oak and the Ivy how they embrace.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: Excellent acquaintance, they shall be the Gemini.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Shall I desire your name sir?

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p: Master Scattergood.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Of the Scattergoods of London?

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p: No indeed sir, of the Scattergoods of Hampshire.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Good Master Scattergood.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: Come Gentlemen, here is dice.

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p: Please you advance to the Table?

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: No indeed sir.

sp.speaker: Scatt.
sp.p: Pray will you go?

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p:
I will go sir over the whole world for your sake,
But in courtesy I will not budge a foot.

sp.speaker: Nin.
sp.p:
Here is the Cash you sent me for, and master Rash,
Here is a Letter from one of your sisters.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: I have the dice, set Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: From which sister?

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: From the mad-cap, I know by the hand.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: For me, six.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: And six that.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: Nine; one, two, three, four, five, six, seven, and eight: eighteen shillings.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: What is yours sir?

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p: Mine is a Bakers dozen: master Bubble tell your money.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p:
In good faith I am but a simple Gamester, and do not
know what to do.

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p: Why you must tell your money, and he will pay you.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p:
My money! I do know how much my money is, but he
shall not pay me, I have a better conscience than so: what for
throwing the dice twice, i'faith he should have but a hard bargain
of it.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: Witty rascal, I must needs away.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Why what is the matter?

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p:
Why the lovers cannot agree, thou shalt along with
me, and know all.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p:
But first let me instruct thee in the condition of this
Gentleman, whom dost thou take him to be?

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: Nay, he is a stranger, I know him not.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p:
By this light but you do, if his beard were off, it is
Stainal.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p:
The devil it is as soon: and what is his purpose in
this disguise?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p:
Why cheating, do you not see how he plays upon
his worshipful Master, and the rest.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: By my faith he draws apace.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: A pox upon these dice, give us a fresh bale.

sp.speaker: Bubb.
sp.p:
Ha ha, the dice are not to be blamed, a man may perceive
this is no Gentlemanly gamester, by his chafing: do you
hear, my friend, fill me a glass of beer, and there is a shilling
for your pains.

sp.speaker: Dra.
sp.p: Your worship shall sir.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: Why how now Franke, what hast lost?

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p:
Fifteen pounds and upwards: is there never an honest
fellow.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.p: What, do you lack money sir?

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Yes, canst furnish me?

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.p: Upon a sufficient pawn sir.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p:
You know my shop, bid my man deliver you a piece
of three pile velvet, and let me have as much money as you
dare adventure upon it.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.p: You shall sir.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p:
A pox of this luck, it will not last ever:
Play sir, I will set you.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p:
Franke, better fortune befall thee: and Gentleman, I
must take my leave, for I must leave you.

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p: Must you needs be gone?

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: Indeed I must.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Yes truly.

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p: At your discretions Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: Farewell.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p:
Cry you mercy sir, I am chanced with you all Gentlemen:
here I have seven, here seven, and here ten.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: It is right sir, and ten that.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: And nine that.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: Two fives at all.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: One and five that.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p:
Um, and can a suite of Satin cheat so grossly?
By this light there is naught on one die but fives and sixes,
I must not be thus gulled.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Come Master Spendall, set.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: No sir, I have done.

sp.speaker: Scatt.
sp.p:
Why then let us all leave, for I think dinner is near
ready.

sp.speaker: Dra.
sp.p: Your meat is upon the Table.

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p:
On the Table! come Gentlemen, we do our stomachs
wrong: Master. Bubble, what have you lost?

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p:
That is no matter, what I have lost, I have lost; nor
can I choose but smile at the foolishness of the dice.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p:
I am but your steward Gentlemen, for after dinner I
may restore it again.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Master. Scatter-good, will you walk in?

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p:
I will wait upon you sir, come Gentlemen, will you
follow?

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: Yes sir, I will follow you.

sp.speaker: Spen.
sp.p: Hear you sir, a word.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: Ten if you please.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: I have lost fifteen pounds.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: And I have found it

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p:
You say right, found it you have indeed,
But never won it: do you know this die?

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: Not I sir.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p:
You seem a Gentleman, and you may perceive
I have some respect unto your credit,
To take you thus aside, will you restore
What you have drawn from me unlawfully?

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p:
Sirrah, by your out-side you seem a citizen,
Whose Coxcomb, I were apt enough to break,
But for the Law; go you are a prating Jack,
Nor is it your hopes, of crying out for clubs,
Can save you from my chastisement, if once
You shall but dare to utter this again.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: You lie, you dare not.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: Lie! nay villain, now thou tempest me to thy death.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p:
Soft, you must buy it dearer,
The best blood flows within you is the price.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: Darest thou resist, thou art no Citizen.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: I am a Citizen.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p:
Say thou art a Gentleman, and I am satisfied,
For then I know thou wilt answer me in field.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p:
I will say directly what I am, a Citizen,
And I will meet thee in the field as fairly
As the best Gentleman that wears a sword.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: I accept it, the meeting place.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Beyond the Maze in Tuttle.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: What weapon?

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Single rapier.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: The time.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Tomorrow.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: The hour.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Betwixt nine and ten.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: It is good, I shall expect you, farewell.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Farewell sir.

body.stage: Enter Will Rash, Long-field, and Ioyce.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p:
Why I commend thee Girl, thou speakest as thou
thinkst, thy tongue and thy heart are Relatives, if thou wert
not my sister, I should at this time fall in love with thee.

sp.speaker: Ioyce.
sp.p:
You should not need, for and you were not my brother,
I should fall in love with you, for I love a proper man
with my heart, and so does all the Sex of us, let my sister dissemble
never so much, I am out of charity with these nice and squeamish
tricks, we were born for men, and men for us, and we
must together.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: This same plain dealing is a Jewel in thee.

sp.speaker: Ioyce.
sp.p:
And let me enjoy that Jewel, for I love plain dealing
with my heart.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p:
Thou art a good wench i'faith, I should never be ashamed
to call thee sister, though thou shouldst marry a Broom-man:
but your lover methinks is over-tedious.

sp.speaker: Ioyce.
sp.p:
No, look ye sir, could you wish a man to come better
upon his cue, let us withdraw.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p:
Close, close, for the prosecution of the plot, wench,
See he prepares.

sp.speaker: Ioyce.
sp.p: Silence.

sp.speaker: Gerald.
sp.p:
The Sun is yet wrapped in Auroraes arms,
And lulled with her delight, forgets his creatures:
Awake thou god of beat,
I call thee up, and task thee for thy slowness;
Point all thy beams through yonder flaring glass,
And raise a beauty brighter than thyself;
Musicians, give to each Instruments a tongue,
To breathe sweet music in the ears of her
To whom I send it as a messenger.

sp.speaker: Gart.
Ger.
sp.p:
Leave me not entranced: sing not my death,
Thy voice is able to make Satires tame,
And call rough winds to her obedience.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p:
Sir, sir, our ears itch not for flattery, here you besiege
my window, that I dare not put forth myself to take the
gentle Air, but you are in the fields, and volley out your
woes, your plaints, your loves, your injuries.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p:
Since you have heard, and know them, give redress,
True beauty never yet was merciless.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p:
Sir, rest thus satisfied, my mind was never woman,
never altered, nor shall it now begin:
So fare you well.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p:
Sfoot, she plays the terrible tyrannising Tamberlaine
over him, this it is to turn Turk, from a most absolute complete
Gentleman, to a most absurd ridiculous and fond lover.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p:
O, when a woman knows the power and authority
of her eye.

sp.speaker: Ioyce.
sp.p:
Fie upon her, she is good for nothing then, no more
than a jade that knows his own strength: The window is
clasped, now brother, pursue your project, and deliver your
friend from the tyranny of my domineering sister.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p:
Do you hear, you drunkard in love, come in to
us and be ruled, you would little think, that the wench that
talked so scurvily out of the window there, is more enamoured
on thee than thou on her: nay, look you now, see if he
turn not away slighting our good counsel: I am no Christian
if she do not sigh, whine, and grow sick for thee:
look you sir, I will bring you in good witness against her.

sp.speaker: Ioyce.
sp.p:
Sir, you are my brothers friend, and I will be plain with
you, you do not take the course to win my sister, but indirectly
go about the bush: you come and fiddle here, and
keep a coil in verse: hold off your hat, and beg to kiss
her hand, which makes her proud. But to be short, in two
lines thus it is:
Who most doth love, must seem most to neglect it,
For those that show most love, are least respected.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: A good observation by my faith.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p:
Well this instruction comes too late now,
Stand you close, and let me prosecute my invention,
Sister, O sister, wake, arise sister.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: How now brother, why call you with such terror?

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p:
How can you sleep so sound, and hear such groans,
So horrid and so tedious to the ear,
That I was frighted hither by the sound?
O sister, here lies a Gentleman that loved you too dearly,
And himself too ill, as by his death appears,
I can report no further without tears;
Assist me now.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p:
When he came first, death startled in his eyes,
His hand had not forsook the dagger hilt,
But still he gave it strength, as if he feared
He had not sent it home unto his heart.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p:
Enough, enough,
If you will have me live, give him no name,
Suspicion tells me it is my Geraldine:
But be it whom it will, I will come to him,
To suffer death as resolute as he.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: Did not I tell you it would take, down sir down.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: I guess what you would have me do.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: O for a little blood to besprinkle him.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p:
No matter for blood, I will not suffer her to come near
him, till the plot have taken his full height.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: A scarf over my face, lest I betray myself.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p:
Here, here, lie still, she comes,
Now Mercury, be propitious.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p:
Where lies this spectacle of blood?
This tragic Scene.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: Yonder lies Geraldine.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p:
O let me see him with his face of death!
Why do you stay me from my Geraldine?

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p:
Because, unworthy as thou art, thou shalt not see
The man now dead, whom living thou didst scorn,
The worst part that he had, deserved thy best,
But yet contemned, deluded, mocked, despised by you,
Unfit for aught but for the general mark
Which you were made for, man's creation.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p:
Burst not my heart before I see my Love,
Brother, upon my knees I beg your leave,
That I may see the wound of Geraldine,
I will embalm his body with my tears,
And carry him unto his sepulcher,
From whence I will never rise, but be interred
In the same dust he shall be buried in.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p:
I do protest she draws sad tears from me,
I prithee let her see her Geraldine.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p:
Brother, if ever you loved me as a sister,
Deprive me not the sight of Geraldine.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p:
Well, I am contented you shall touch his lips,
But neither see his face nor yet his wound,

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: Not see his face?

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p:
Nay, I have sworn it to the contrary:
Nay, hark you further yet.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: What now?

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: But one kiss, no more.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: Why then no more.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p:
Marry this liberty I will give you,
If you intend to make any speech of repentance
Over him, I am content, so it be short.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: What you command is Law, and I obey.

sp.speaker: Ioyce.
sp.p: Peace, give ear to the passion.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p:
Before I touch thy body, I implore
Thy discontented ghost to be appeased:
Send not unto me till I come myself:
Then shalt thou know how much I honoured thee.
O see the colour of his coral lip!
Which in despite of death lives full and fresh,
As when he was the beauty of his Sex:
It were sin worthy the worst of plagues to leave thee:
Not all the strength and policy of man.
Shall snatch me from thy bosom.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Look, look, I think she will ravish him.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: Why how now sister?

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p:
Shall we have both one grave? here I am chained,
Thunder nor Earthquakes shall shake me off.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p:
No? I will try that, come dead man, awake, up with your
bag and baggage, and let us have no more fooling.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: And lives my Geraldine?

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p:
Live? faith Aye,
Why should he not? he was never dead,
That I know of.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p:
It is no wonder Geraldine should live,
Though he had emptied all his vital spirits,
The Lute of Orpheus spake not half so sweet,
When he descended to the infernal vaults,
To fetch again his fair Euridice,
As did thy sweet voice to Geraldine.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p:
I will exercise that voice, since it doth please
My better self, my constant Geraldine.

sp.speaker: Ioyce.
sp.p:
Why so la, here is an end of an old Song,
Why could not this have been done before
I pray?

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p:
O you are a goodly sister, this is your plot:
Well, I shall live one day to requite you.

sp.speaker: Ioyce.
sp.p:
Spare me not, for wheresoever I set my affection, although
it be upon a Collier, if I fall back, unless it be in the
right kind, bind me to a stake, and let me be burned to
death with charcoal.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p:
Well, thou art a mad wench, and there is no more to
be done at this time, but as we brought you together, so to
part you, you must not lie at rack and manger: there be those
within, that will forbid the banes, Time must shake good Fortune
by the hand, before you two must be great, specially you
sister; come leave swearing.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: Must we then part?

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p:
Must you part? why how think you? vdsfoote, I do
think we shall have as much to do to get her from him, as we
had to bring her to him: this love of women is of a strange
quality, and has more tricks than a Juggler.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: But this, and then farewell.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Thy company is heaven, thy absence hell.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: Lord who would think it?

sp.speaker: Ioyce.
sp.p: Come wench.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: This ground is firm and even, I will go no further.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p:
This be the place then, and prepare you sir,
You shall have fair play for your life of me,
For look sir, I will be open breasted to you.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p:
Shame light on him that thinks his safety lieth in a
French doublet.
Nay I would strip myself, would comeliness.
Give sufferance to the deed, and fight with thee,
As naked as a Mauritanian Moore.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p:
Give me thy hand, by my heart I love thee,
Thou art the highest spirited Citizen,
That ever Guild-hall took notice of.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Talk not what I am, until you have tried me.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: Come on sir.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Now sir, your life is mine.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: Why then take it, for I will not beg it of thee.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p:
Nobly resolved, I love thee for those words,
Here take thy arms again, and if thy malice
Have spent itself like mine, then let us part
More friendly than we met at first encounter.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p:
Sir, I accept this gift of you, but not your friendship,
Until I shall recover it with my honour.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Will you fight again then?

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p:
Faith thou dost well then, justly to whip my folly.
But come sir.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: Hold, you are hurt I take it.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Hurt! where? zownds I feel it not.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: You bleed I am sure.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p:
Sblood, I think you wear a cat's claw upon your
Rapiers point,
I am scratched indeed, but small as it is,
I must have blood for blood.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: You are bent to kill I see.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p:
No by my hopes, if I can scape that sin,
And keep my good name, I will never offer it.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: Well sir, your worst.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p:
We both bleed now I take it,
And if the motion may be equal thought,
To part with clasped hands: I shall first subscribe.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p:
It were unmanliness in me to refuse
The safety of us both, my hand shall never fall
From such a charitable motion.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p:
Then join we both, and here our malice ends,
Though foes we came to the field, we will depart friends.

body.stage: Enter sir Lyonell and a Seruant.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p:
Come, come, follow me knave, follow me, I have the
best nose in the house, I think, either we shall have rainy weather,
or the vaults unstopped: sirrah, go see, I would not have
my guess smell out any such inconvenience: Do you hear
sirrah Symon?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p:
Bid the Kitchen-maid scour the sink, and make
clean her backside, for the wind lies just upon it.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: I will sir.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p:
And bid Anthonie put on his white fustian doublet,
for he must wait today: It doth me so much good to stir
and talk, to place this, and displace that, that I shall need no
Apothecaries prescriptions, I have sent my daughter this morning
as far as Pimliko to fetch a draught of Darby ale, that it
may fetch a colour in her cheeks, the pulling harlotry looks
so pale, and it is all for want of a man, for so their mother
would say, God rest her soul, before she died.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Sir, the Gentlemen are come already.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: How knave, the Gentlemen!

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Yes sir, yonder they are.

sp.speaker: Lyonell.
sp.p:
Gods precious, we are too tardy, let one be sent
presently to meet the girls, and hasten their coming home
quickly: how dost thou stand dreaming? Gentlemen, I see
you love me, you are careful of your hour; you may be deceived
in your cheer, but not in your welcome.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Thanks, and Tu quoque is a word for all.

sp.speaker: Scatterg.
sp.p:
A pretty concise room: sir Lyonell, where are
your daughters?

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: They are at your service sir, and forth coming.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p:
Gods will Geruase! how shall I behave myself to
the Gentlewomen?

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p:
Why advance yourself toward them, with a comely
steppe, and in your salute, be careful you strike not too high,
nor too low, and afterwards for your discourse, your Tu quoque
will bear you out.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p:
Nay, if that be all, I care not, for I will set a good face
on it, that is flat: and for my nether parts, let them speak for
themselves: here is a leg, and ever a Baker in England show
me a better, I will give him mine for nothing.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: O that is a special thing that I must caution you of.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: What sweet Geruase?

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p:
Why for commending yourself; never whilst you
live commend yourself: and then you shall have the Ladies
themselves commend you.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: I would they would else.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p:
Why they will I will assure you sir, and the more vilely
you speak of yourself, the more will they strive to collaud
you.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p:
Let me alone to dispraise myself,
I will make myself the arrantest Coxcomb within a whole
Country.

sp.speaker: Lyonell.
sp.p:
Here come the Gypsies, the Sunburned girls,
Whose beauties will not utter them alone,
They must have bags although my credit crack for it.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Is this the eldest sir?

sp.speaker: Lyonell.
sp.p: Yes marry is she sir.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: I will kiss the youngest first, because she likes me best.

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p:
Marry sir, and whilst you are there, I will be here:
O delicious touch! I think in conscience
Her lips are lined quite through with Orange Tawny velvet.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p:
They kiss exceeding well, I do not think but they
have been brought up to it, I will begin to her like a Gentleman
in a set speech: Fair Lady, shall I speak a word with
you?

sp.speaker: Ioyce.
sp.p: With me sir?

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p:
With you Lady, - this way, - a little more -
So now it is well, um -
Even as a Drummer, - or a Pewterer.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p:
Which of the two no matter.
For one beats on a Drum, the other a Platter.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p:
In good faith sweet Lady you say true
But pray mark me further, I will begin again.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p: I pray Sir do.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p:
Even as a Drummer, as I said before, -
Or as a Pewterer.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p: Very good Sir.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Do - do - do.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p: What do they do?

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p:
By my troth Lady, I do not know: for to say truth,
I am a kind of an Ass.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p: How Sir, an Ass?

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Yes indeed Lady.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p: Nay that you are not.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p:
So God ha me, I am Lady: you never saw
an arranter Ass in your life.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p: Why here is a Gentleman your friend, will not say so.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p:
I'faith but he shall: How say you sir,
Am not I an Ass?

sp.speaker: Scatt.
sp.p:
Yes by my troth Lady is he: Why I will say anything
my brother Bubble says.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p:
Is this the man my Father choose for me,
to make a Husband of? O God, how blind
are parents in our loves: so they have wealth,
they care not to what things they marry us.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Pray look upon me Lady.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p: So I do sir.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p:
Aye but look upon me well, and tell me if you ever
saw any man look so scurvily, as I do?

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p: The fellow sure is frantic.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: You do not mark me?

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p: Yes indeed sir.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p:
Aye, but look upon me well:
Did you ever see a worse timbered Leg?

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p: By my faith it is a pretty four square Leg.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p:
Aye but your four square Legs are none of the best.
O! Iaruis, Iaruis.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: Excellent well sir.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p:
What say you now to me Lady, can you find
ever a good inch about me?

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p: Yes that I can sir.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p:
Find it, and take it sweet Lady:
There I think I bobbed her, Iaruis?

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p:
Well sir, disparage not yourself so: for if you were
The man you would make yourself; yet out of your
Behaviour and discourse, I could find cause enough
To love you.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p:
Ugh! now she comes to me: My behaviour? alas,
alas, it is clownical, and my discourse is very bald, bald:
You shall not hear me break a good Jest
in a twelve month.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p: No sir? why now you break a good Jest.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p:
No, I want the Boone Ioure, and the Tu quoques,
Which yonder Gentleman has: There is a bob for him too:
There is a Gentleman, and you talk of a Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p: Who he? he is a Coxcomb indeed.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: We are sworn Brothers in good faith Lady.

sp.speaker: Scatt.
sp.p:
Yes in truth we are sworn Brothers, and do mean
to go both alike, and to have Horses alike.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p: And they shall be sworn Brothers too?

sp.speaker: Scatt.
sp.p: If it please them, Lady.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Master. Balance, the Goldsmith desires to speak with you.

sp.speaker: Lyo.
sp.p: Bid him come, knave.

sp.speaker: Scatt.
sp.p:
I wonder (Sir Lyonell) your son Will Rash is not
here?

sp.speaker: Lyo.
sp.p: Is he of your acquaintance, sir?

sp.speaker: Scatt.
sp.p:
O very familiar, he struck me a box on the ear
once, and from thence grew my love to him.

sp.speaker: Lyo.
sp.p:
It was a sign of virtue in you sir; but he will be here
at dinner. Master Balance, what makes you so strange?
Come, you are welcome: what is the News?

sp.speaker: Balla.
sp.p:
Why sir, the old News: your man Francis riots still,
And little hope of thrift there is in him;
Therefore I come to advise your Worship,
To take some order whilst there is something left,
The better part of his best Ware is consumed.

sp.speaker: Lyo.
sp.p:
Speak softly Master Balance.
But is there no hope of his recovery?

sp.speaker: Ball.
sp.p:
None at all sir; for he is already laid to be arrested by
some that I know.

sp.speaker: Lyo.
sp.p:
Well, I do suffer for him, and am loath
Indeed to do, what I am constrained to do:
Well sir, I mean to seize on what is left.
And hark you one word more.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p:
What heinous sin has yonder man committed,
To have so great a punishment, as wait
upon the humours of an idle Fool:
A very proper Fellow, good Leg, good Face,
A Body well proportioned: but his mind
Bewrays he never came of Generous kind.

sp.speaker: Lyo.
sp.p:
Go to, no more of this at this time.
What sir, are you come?

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: Yes sir, and have made bold to bring a Guest along.

sp.speaker: Lyo.
sp.p: Master Geraldines son of Essex?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: The same sir.

sp.speaker: Lyo.
sp.p: Ye are welcome sir, when will your Father be in town?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: It will not be long, sir.

sp.speaker: Lyo.
