sp.p: I shall be glad to see him when he comes.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: I thank, you sir.

sp.speaker: Lyo.
sp.p:
In the mean time you are welcome; pray be not strange,
I will leave my Son amongst you Gentlemen,
I have some business: hark you Master. Balance,
Dinner will soon be ready; one word more

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p:
And how does my little Asinus and his Tu quoque here?
O you pretty sweet-faced rogues, that for your countenances
might be Alexander and Lodwicke: What says the old man to
you? will it be a match? shall we call Brothers?

sp.speaker: Scatt.
sp.p:
Aye faith with all my heart; if Mistress Gartred will,
we will be married tomorrow.

sp.speaker: Bub:
sp.p: Uds foot, if Mistress Joyce will, we will be married tonight.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p:
Why you courageous Boys, and worthy Wenches,
made out of Wax. But what shall us do when we have
dined, shall us go see a Play?

sp.speaker: Scatt.
sp.p:
Yes faith Brother: if it please you, let us go see
a Play at the Globe.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p:
I care not; any whither, so the Clown have a part:
For I'faith I am nobody without a Fool.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Why then we will go to the Red Bull; they say Green is a good Clown.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Greene? Greene is an Ass.

sp.speaker: Scatt.
sp.p: Wherefore do you say so?

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p:
Indeed I have no reason: for they say, he is as like me
as ever he can look.

sp.speaker: Scatt.
sp.p: Well then, to the Bull.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: A good resolution, continue it: nay on?

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Not before the Gentle women; not I never.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p:
O while you live, men before women:
Custom hath placed it so.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Why then Custom is not so mannerly, as I would be.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p:
Farewell Master. Scatter-good: Come Lover, you are too
busy here, I must tutor ye: Cast not your eye at the table on
each other my Father will spy you without Spectacles,
He is a shrewd observer: do you hear me?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Very well sir.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p:
Come then go we together, let the Wenches alone.
Do you see yonder fellow?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Yes: prithee what is he?

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p:
I will give you him within, he must not now be thought
on: but you shall know him.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p:
I have observed my sister, and her eye
Is much inquisitive after yond fellow;
She has examined him from head to foot:
I will stay and see the issue.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p:
To wrestle gainst the stream of our Affection,
Is to strike Air, or buffet with the Wind,
That plays upon us: I have strived to cast
This fellow from my thoughts, but still he grows
More comely in my sight; yet a slave
Unto one worse conditioned than a slave:
They are all gone, here is none but he, and I,
Now I will speak to him: and yet I will not.
O! I wrong myself, I will suppress
That insurrection Love hath trained in me,
And leave him as he is: once my bold spirits
Had vowed to utter all my thoughts to him
On whom I settled my affection:
And why retires it now?

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p:
Fight Love on both sides; for on me thou strikest
Strokes that hath beat my Heart into a flame:
She hath sent amorous glances from her eye:
Which I have back returned as faithfully.
I would make to her, but these servile Robes,
Curbs that suggestion, till some fitter time
Shall bring me more persuadingly unto her.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p:
I wonder why he stays; I fear he notes me,
For I have publicly betrayed myself,
By too much gazing on him: I will leave him.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p:
But you shall not; I will make you speak to him
Before you go. Do you hear sir?

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p: What mean you sister?

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p:
To fit you in your kind, sister: do you remember
How you once tyrannized over me?

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p:
Nay prithee leave this jesting,
I am out of the vain.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: Aye, but I am in: go speak to your Lover.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p: I will first be buried quick.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p:
How, ashamed? Uds foot, I trow, if I had set my affection
on a Collier, I would never fall back, unless it were in the right
kind: if I did, let me be tied to a Stake, and burnt to death
with Charcoal.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p: Nay then we shall hate.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: Yes marry shall you. Sister, will you speak to him:

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p:
Do you hear sir? here is a Gentlewoman would
speak with you.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p: Why Sister, I pray Sister.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p:
One that loves you with all her heart,
Yet is ashamed to confess it.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: Did you call, Ladies?

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p: No sir, here is no-one called.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: Yes sir it was I, I called to speak with your.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p:
My Sister is somewhat frantic; there is no regard to
be had unto her clamours: Will you yet leave?
I'faith you will anger me.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p:
Passion: Come back fool lover, turn again and
kiss your belly full, here is one will stand ye.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: What does this mean trow?

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p: Yes, is your humour spent?

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p:
Come let me go, Birds that want the use of
Reason and of Speech, can couple together in one day;
And yet you that have both, cannot conclude in twenty:
now Sister I am even with you, my venom is spit,
As much happiness may you enjoy with your lover as I with mine:
And droop not wench, nor never be ashamed of him,
The man will serve the turn, though he be wrapped
In a blue Coat, I will warrant him, come.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p: You are merrily disposed, Sister.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p:
I needs must prosper, Fortune and Love work for me.
Be moderate my Joys; for as you grow to your full height,
So Bubbles waxeth low.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: Will my sweet Spendall be gone then?

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p:
I must upon promise; but I will be here at supper:
Therefore Mistress Sweatman, provide us some good cheer.

sp.speaker: Sweat.
sp.p: The best the Market will yield.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p:
Here is twenty shillings; I protest I have left myself
but a Crown, for my spending money: for indeed I intend to
be frugal, and turn good husband.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p:
Aye marry will you, you will to play again, and lose your
Money and fall to fighting; my very heart trembles to think
on it: how if you had been killed in the quarrel, of my faith
I had been but a dead woman.

sp.speaker: Spen.
sp.p: Come, come, no more of this; thou dost but dissemble.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p:
Dissemble? do not you say so; for if you do,
Gods my judge I will give myself a gash.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Away, away, prithee no more: farewell.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p:
Nay buss first: Well,
There is no adversity in the world shall part us.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Thou art a loving Rascal; farewell.

sp.speaker: Sweat.
sp.p: You will not fail supper?

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: You have my word; farewell.

sp.speaker: 1. Ser.
sp.p: Sir, we arrest you.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Arrest me, at whose suite?

sp.speaker: 2. Ser.
sp.p:
Marry there is suites enough against you,
I will warrant you.

sp.speaker: 1. Ser.
sp.p: Come, away with him.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Stay, hear me a word.

sp.speaker: 2. Ser.
sp.p: What do you say?

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: How now Purssuet, why comest in such haste?

sp.speaker: Purss.
sp.p:
Shut up your doors, and bar young Spendall out.
And let him be cashiered your company,
He is turned Bankrupt, his wares are seized on,
And his shop shut up.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: How, his wares seized on? thou dost but jest, I hope.

sp.speaker: Purss.
sp.p:
What this tongue doth report, these eyes have seen,
It is no Aesop's fable that I tell,
But it is true, as I am faithful Pander.

sp.speaker: Sweat.
sp.p:
Nay I did ever think the prodigal would prove
A Bankrupt; but hang him, let him rot
In prison, he comes no more within these doors
I warrant him.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p:
Come hither, I would he would but offer it,
We will fire him out with a pox to him.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p:
Will you do it;
To carry me to prison, but undoes me?

sp.speaker: 1. Sar.
sp.p: What say you fellow Gripe, shall we take his forty shillings.

sp.speaker: 2. Sar.
sp.p: Yes faith, we shall have him again within this week.

sp.speaker: 1. Sar.
sp.p: Well Sir, your forty shillings? and we will have some compassion on you.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p:
Will you but walk with me unto that house,
And there you shall receive it.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: What, where the women are?

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: Sweat.
Purss.
sp.p: It is the best course Mistress Tickleman?

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p:
But I say no, you shall not stir a foot,
For I will talk with him,

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p:
Nan, I am come
Even in the Minute that thou didst profess
Kindness unto me, to make try all of it,
Adversity thou Sees lays hands upon me,
But Forty shillings will deliver me,

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p:
Why you Impudent Rogue, do you come to me for Money?
Or do I know you? what acquaintance pray,
Hath ever past betwixt yourself and me?

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p:
Zounds do you mock us, to bring us to these women
that do not know you?

sp.speaker: Sweat.
sp.p:
Yes in good Sooth, (Officers I take it you are)
He is a mere stranger here: only in charity,
Sometimes we have relieved him with a meal.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p:
This is not earnest in you? Come, I know
My gifts and bounty cannot be soon buried:
Go prithee fetch Forty shillings?

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p:
Talk not to me (you slave) of Forty shillings;
For by this light that shines, ask it again,
I will send my Knife of an errand in your Guts:
A shameless Rogue to come to me for Money?

sp.speaker: Sweat.
sp.p: Is he your Prisoner, Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Yes marry is he.

sp.speaker: Sweat.
sp.p:
Pray carry him then to Prison, let him smart for it,
Perhaps it will tame the wildness of his youth,
And teach him how to lead a better life:
He had good counsel here, I can assure you,
And if he would a took it.

sp.speaker: Purss.
sp.p: I told him still myself, what would ensue.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p:
Furies break loose in me: Sergeants, let me go, I will
give you all I have, to purchase freedom but for a lightning
while, to tear yond Whore, Bawd, Pander; and in them, the
Devil: for there is his Hell, his habitation; nor has he any
other local place.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: No sir, we will take no Bribes.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p:
Honest Sergeants, give me leave to unlade
A heart over-charged with grief; as I have a soul,
I will not break from you.
Thou Strumpet, that wert born to ruin men,
My fame, and fortune: be subject to my Curse,
And hear me speak it: Mayst thou in thy youth,
Feel the sharpe Whip; and in thy Beldam age,
The Cart: when thou art grown to be
And old Upholster unto Venery,
(A Bawd I mean, to live by Feather beds,)
Mayst thou be driven to sell all thou hast
Unto thy Aqua vite Bottle; that is the last
A Bawd will part withal; and live so poor,
That being turned forth thy house, mayst die at door.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Come sir, have you done?

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p:
A little further give me leave, I pray,
I have a charitable Prayer to end with.
May the French Cannibal eat into thy flesh,
And pick thy bones so clean, that the report
Of thy Calamity, may draw resort
Of all the common Sinners in the town,
To see thy mangled Carcass: and that then,
They may upon it, turn honest; Bawd, say Amen.

sp.speaker: Sweat.
sp.p: Out upon him wicked villain, how he blasphemes;

sp.speaker: Purss.
sp.p: He will be damned for turning Heretic.

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p:
Hang him Bankrupt rascal, let him talk in Prison,
The whilst we will spend his Goods: for I did never
Hear, that men took example by each other.

sp.speaker: Sweat.
sp.p:
Well, if men did rightly consider it, they should find,
That Whores and Bawds are profitable members
In a Common-wealth: for indeed, though we somewhat
Impair their Bodies, yet we do good to their Souls;
For I am sure, we still bring them to Repentance.

sp.speaker: Purss.
sp.p: By Dis, and so we do.

sp.speaker: Sweat.
sp.p:
Come, come, will you Dis before: thou art one of
them, that I warrant thee wilt be hanged, before thou wilt
repent.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p:
Well, this Love is a troublesome thing, Jupiter bless
me out of his fingers: there is no estate can rest for him:
He runs through all Countries, will travel through the
Isle of Man in a minute; but never is quiet till he come into
Middle-sex, and there keeps his Christmas:
It is his habitation, his mansion; from whence,
He will never out, till he be fired.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p:
Well, do not tyrannize too much, lest one day he make
you know his Deity, by sending a shaft out of a sparkling
eye, shall strike so deep into your heart, that it shall make you
fetch your breath short again.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p:
And make me cry, O eyes no eyes, but two celestial
Stars! A pox on it, I would as lieve hear a fellow sing through
the nose. How now Wench!

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p:
Keep your station; you stand as well for the encounter
as may be: She is coming on; but as melancholy, as a
Base-viol in Consort.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p:
Which makes thee as Sprightly as the Treble.
Now dost thou play thy prize: here is the honourable Science
one against another: Do you hear Lover, the thing is done
you wot off; you shall have your Wench alone without any
disturbance: now if you can do any good, why so, the Silver
Game be yours, we will stand by and give aim, and hallow if.
you hit the Clout.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p:
It is all the assistance I request of you,
Bring me but opportunately to her presence,
And I desire no more: and if I cannot win her,
Let me lose her.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p:
Well sir, let me tell you, perhaps you undertake
A harder task than yet you do imagine.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p:
A task, what to win a Woman, and have opportunity?
I would that were a task i'faith, for any man that wears his
wits about him: give me but half an hour's
Conference with the coldest creature of them all,
And if I bring her not into a fool's Paradise,
I will pull out my tongue, and hang it at her door for a draw-latch.
Vdsfoot, I would never stand thrumming of Caps for the matter,
I will quickly make trial of her if she love:
To have her Beauty praised, I will praise it: if her Wit,
I will commender it: if her good parts, I will exalt them.
No course shall scape me; for to whatsoever I saw her inclined
to, to that would I fit her.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p:
But you must not do thus to her, for she is a subtle
flouting rogue, that will laugh you out of countenance, if you
solicit her seriously: No, talk me to her wantonly, slightly and
carelessly, and perhaps so you may prevail as much with her.
as wind does with a Sail, carry her whither thou wilt, Bully.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: Well sir, I will follow your instruction.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p:
Do so. And see she appears; fall you two off from us,
Let us two walk together.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p:
Why did my enquiring eye take in this fellow,
And let him down so easy to my heart;
Where like a Conqueror he ceases on it,
And beats all other men out of my Bosom!

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p:
Sister, you are well met,
Here is a Gentleman desires to be acquainted with you.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p:
See, the Serving-man is turned a Gentleman,
That villainous Wench my Sister, has no mercy,
She and my Brother has conspired together to play upon me;
But I will prevent their sport: for rather than my tongue shall
have scope to speak matter to give them mirth, my heart shall
break.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p:
You have your desire sir, I will leave you;
Grapple with her as you can.

sp.speaker: Sat.
sp.p:
Lady, God save you. She turns back upon the motion,
There is no good to be done by braying for her, I see that;
I must plunge into a passion: now for a piece of Hero and
Leander: it were excellent; and praise be to my memory,
It has reached half a dozen lines for the purpose:
Well, she shall have them.
One is no Number; Maids are nothing then
Without the sweet society of Men.
Will thou live single still? one shalt thou be,
Though never singling Hymen couple thee.
Wild Savages that drink of running Springs,
Thinks Water far excels all other thing.
They that daily taste neat Wine, despise it.
Virginity albeit some highly prize it,
Compared with Marriage, had you tried them both,
Differs as much, as Wine and Water doth. No?
Why then have at you in another kind.
By the faith of a Soldier (Lady) I do reverence the
ground that you walk upon: I will fight with him that
dares say you are not fair: Stab him that will not pledge
your health; and with a Dagger pierce a Vain, to drink a
full health to you; but it shall be on this condition, that you
shall speak first.
Uds foot, if I could but get her to talk once, half my labour
were over: but I will try her in an other vain.
What an excellent creature is a Woman without a tongue?
But what a more excellent creature is a Woman that has a
tongue, and can hold her peace? But how much more excellent
and fortunate a creature is that man, that has that
Woman to his wife? This cannot choose but mad her;
And if anything make a Woman talk, it is this. It will not do
though yet I pray God they have not gulled me:
But I will try once again.
When will that tongue take liberty to talk?
Speak but one word, and I am satisfied:
Or do but say but Mum, and I am answered?
No sound? no accent? Is there no noise in Woman?
Nay then without direction I have done.
I must go call for help.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: How, not speak?

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p:
Not a syllable, night nor sleep, is not more silent:
She is as dumb as Westminster Hall, in the long vacation.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: Well, and what would you have me do?

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: Why, make her speak.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: And what then?

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: Why, let me alone with her.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p:
Aye, so you said before, Give you but opportunity,
And let you alone, you would desire no more; but come,
I will try my cunning for you: See what I can do.
How do you Sister, I am sorry to hear you are not well,
This Gent. tells me you have lost your tongue, I pray let us see?
If you can but make signs whereabout you lost it,
We will go and look for it: in good faith Sister, you look very pale,
In my conscience it is for grief: will you have
Any comfortable Drinks sent for, this is not the way;
Come walk, seem earnest in discourse, cast not an eye
Towards her, and you shall see weakness work itself.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p:
My heart is swollen so big, that it must vent,
Or it will burst: Are you a Brother?

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p:
Look to yourself Sir,
The Brazen head has spoke, and I must leave you.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p:
Has shame that power in him, to make him fly:
And dare you be so impudent to stand
Just in the face of my incensed anger?
What are you? why do you stay? who sent for you?
You were in Garments yesterday, befitting
A fellow of your fashion; has a Crown
Purchased that shining Satin of the Brokers?
Or is it a cast Suite of your goodly Masters.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: A Cast suite, Lady?

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p:
You think it does become: you: faith it does not,
A Blue Coat with a Badge, does better with you.
Go untruss your Master's Points, and do not dare
To stop your Nose when as his Worship stinks:
It has been your breeding.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: Uds life, this is excellent: now she talks.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p:
Nay, were you a Gentleman: and which is more;
Well Landed, I should hardly love you:
For, for your Face, I never saw a worse,
It looks as if it were drawn with yellow Ochre
Upon black Buckram: and that Hair
That is on your Chin, looks not like Beard,
But as if it had been smeared with Shoemaker's Wax.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: Vdsfoot, she will make me out of love with myself.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p:
How dares your Baseness once aspire unto
So high a fortune, as to reach at me:
Because you have heard, that some have run away
With Butlers, Horse-keepers, and their fathers Clerks;
You forsooth, cockered with your own suggestion,
Take heart upon it, and think me, (that am meat
And set up for your Master) fit for you.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: I would I could get her now to hold her tongue.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p:
Or cause, some times as I have past along,
And have returned a Curtsy for your Hat;
You (as the common tricks is) straight suppose,
It is Love, (sir-reverence, which makes the word more beastly.)

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: Why, it is worse than silence.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p:
But we are fools, and in our reputations
We find the smart of it:
Kindness, is termed Lightness, in our sex:
And when we give a Favour, or a Kiss,
We give our Good names too.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: Will you be dumb again.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p:
Men you are called, but you are a viperous brood,
Whom we in charity take into our bosoms,
And cherish with our heart: for which, you sting us.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p:
Uds foot, I will fetch him that waked your tongue,
To lay it down again.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: Why how now man?

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p:
O relieve me, or I shall lose my hearing,
You have raised a Fury up into her tongue
A Parliament of women could not make
Such a Confused noise as that she utters.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: Well, what would you have me do?

sp.speaker: Sat.
sp.p: Why make her hold her tongue.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: And what then?

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: Why then let me alone again.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p:
This is very good I'faith, first give thee but opportunity,
and let thee alone: then make her but Speak, and let
Thee alone: now make her hold her tongue, and then
Let her alone: By my troth I think I were best to let
Thee alone indeed: but come, follow me,
The Wildcat shall not carry it so away,
Walk, walk, as we did.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p:
What, have you fetched your Champion? what can he do?
Not have you, nor himself from out the storm
Of my incensed rage; I will thunder into your ears,
The wrongs that you have done an innocent Maid:
O you are a couple of sweet: What shall I call you?
Men you are not; for if you were,
You would not offer this unto a Maid.
Wherein have I deserved it at your hands? Have I not been,
always a kind Sister to you; and in signs and tokens showed it?
Did I not send Money to you at Cambridge when you were
but a Freshman, wrought you Purses and Bands; and since
you came to the Inns of Court, a fair pair of Hangers? Have
you not taken Rings from me, which I have been fain to say
I have lost, when you had pawned them: and yet was never beholding
to you for a pair of Gloves?

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p:
A Woman's tongue I see, is like a Bell,
That once being set a going, goes itself.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p:
And yet you to join with my sister against me,
Send one here to play upon me, whilst you laugh and leer,
And make a pastime on me: is this Brotherly done?
No it is Barbarous, and a Turk would blush to offer it to a Christian:
but I will think of it, and have it written in my heart,
when it hath slipped your memories.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: When will your tongue be weary?

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p: Never.

sp.speaker: Rash.

body.stage: Heere they two talke and rayle what they list; then Rash speakes to Stayns.

sp.speaker: All speake.
sp.p:
Uds foot, dost thou stand by, and do nothing?
Come talk, and drown her clamours.

body.stage: Heere they all three talke, and Ioyce giues ouer weeping, and Exit.

sp.speaker: Gerald.
sp.p: Alas, she is spent i'faith: now the storms over.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: Uds foot, I will follow her as long as I have any breath.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p:
Nay no more now Brother, you have no compassion,
You see she cries.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p:
If I do not wonder she could talk so long, I am a villain,
She eats no Nuts I warrant her: sfoot, I am almost out of breath
With that little I talked: well Gent. Brothers I might say;
For she and I must clap hands upon it: a match for all this.
Pray go in; and Sister, salve the matter, collogue with her
Again, and all shall be well: I have a little business
That must be thought upon, and it is partly for your mirth;
Therefore let me not (though absent) be forgotten:
Farewell.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: We will be mindful of you sir, fare you well.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: How now man, what tired, tired?

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p:
Zounds, if you had talked as much as I did, you
would be tired I warrant: What, is she gone in? I will to her again
whilst my tongue is warm: and if I thought I should
be used to this exercise I wouldst eat every morning an ounce
of Liquorish.

body.stage: Enter Lodge the maister of the Prison, and Lock-fast his man.

sp.speaker: Lodge.
sp.p: Have you summed up those Reckonings?

sp.speaker: Hold.
sp.p: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Lodg.
sp.p: And what is owing me?

sp.speaker: Hold.
sp.p: Theoretician pound odd money.

sp.speaker: Lodg.
sp.p: How much owes the Frenchman?

sp.speaker: Hold.
sp.p: A fortnight's Commons.

sp.speaker: Lodg.
sp.p: Has Spendall any money?

sp.speaker: Hold.
sp.p: Not any sir: and he has sold all his Clothes.

sp.speaker: Lodg.
sp.p:
That fellow would waste Millions if he had them;
Whilst he has Money, no man spends a penny:
Ask him money, and if he say he has none,
Be plain with him, and turn him out of the Ward.

sp.speaker: Hold.
sp.p:
I will sir. Master Spendall,
My Master has sent to you for money.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p:
Money, why does he send to me? does he think
I have the Philosophers Stones, or I can clip or coin?
How does he think I can come by money?

sp.speaker: Hold.
sp.p:
faith sir, his occasions are so great, that he must
have money, or else he can buy no Victuals.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p:
Then we must starve, belike: Vdsfoot thou seest
I have nothing left, that will yield me two shillings.

sp.speaker: Hold.
sp.p:
If you have no money,
You are best remove into some cheaper Ward.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: What Ward should I remove in?

sp.speaker: Hold.
sp.p:
Why to the Two-penny Ward, is likeliest to hold out
with your means: or if you will, you may go into the Hole,
and there you may feed for nothing.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p:
Aye, out of the Alms-basket, where Charity appears
In likeness of a piece of stinking Fish:
Such as they beat Bawds with when they are Carted.

sp.speaker: Hold.
sp.p:
Why sir, do not scorn it, as good men as yourself,
Have been glad to eat Scraps out of the Alms-basket.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p:
And yet slave, thou in pride wilt stop thy nose.
Screw and make faces, talk contemptibly of it,
and of the feeders; surely groom.

sp.speaker: Hold.
sp.p:
Well sir, your malapertness will get you nothing.
Fox.

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.p: Here.

sp.speaker: Hold.
sp.p:
A prisoner to the Hole, take charge of him, and use
him as scurvily as thou canst you shall be taught your duty
sir, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p:
Hence slavish tyrants, instruments of torture,
There is more kindness yet in Whores, than you,
For when a man hath spent all, he may go
And seek his way, they will kick him out of doors;
Not keep him in as you do, and enforce him
To be the subject of their cruelty.
You have no mercy; but be this your comfort.
The punishment and tortures which you do
Inflict on men, the Devils shall on you.

sp.speaker: Hold.
sp.p:
Well sir, you may talk, but you shall see the end,
And who shall have the worst of it.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p:
Why villain, I shall have the worst, I know it,
And am prepared to suffer like a Stoic,
Or else (to speak more properly) like a Stock;
For I have no sense left: dost thou think I have?

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.p: Zounds, I think he is mad?

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p:
Why, thou art in the right; for I am mad indeed,
And have been mad this two year. Dost thou think
I could have spent so much as, I have done
In wares and credit, had I not been mad?
Why thou must know, I had a fair estate,
Which through my riot, I have torn in pieces,
And scattered amongst Bawds, Buffoons, and Whores,
That fawned on me, and by their flatteries,
Rocked all my understanding faculties
Into a pleasant slumber; where I dreamt
Of naught but joy and pleasure: never felt
How I was lulled in sensuality,
Until at last, Affliction waked me:
And lighting up the Taper of my soul,
Led me unto myself; where I might see
A mind and body rent with Misery.

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.p: Who calls?

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.p: Here is the Bread and Meat-man come.

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.p: Well, the Bread and Meat-man, may stay a little.

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.p:
Yes indeed Harry, the Bread and Meat-man, may stay:
But you know our stomachs cannot stay.

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.p: Indeed your Stomach is always first up.

sp.speaker: Bris.
sp.p:
And therefore by right, should be fire served: I have
a stomach like Aqua fortis, it will eat anything:
O father Gatherscrap, here are excellent bits in the Basket.

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.p:
Will you hold your Chops further; by and by you will
drivel into the Basket?

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.p:
Perhaps it may do some good; for there may be a
piece of powdered Beef that wants watering.

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.p: Here sir, here is your share.

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.p: Here is a bit indeed: what is this to a Gargantua stomach?

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.p: Thou art ever grumbling.

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.p:
Zounds, it would make a Dog grumble, to want his
Victuals: I pray give Spendall none, he came into the Hole but
yesternight.

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.p: What, do you refuse it?

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: I cannot eat, I thank you.

sp.speaker: Pris.
Fox.
sp.p: Divide it then amongst you.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p:
To such a one as these are, must I come,
Hunger will draw me into their fellowship,
To fight and scramble for unsavoury Scraps,
That come from unknown hands, perhaps unwashed:
And would that were the worst; for I have noted,
That naught goes to the Prisoners, but such food
As either by the weather has been tainted,
Or Children, nay sometimes full paunched Dogs,
Have overlicked, as if men had determined
That the worst Sustenance, which is Gods Creatures,
How ever they are abused, are good enough
For such vild Creatures as abuse themselves.
O what a Slave was I unto my Pleasures?
How drowned in Sin, and overwhelmed in Lust?
That I could write my repentance to the world,
And force the impression of it in the hearts
Of you, and my acquaintance, I might teach them
By my example, to look home to Thrift,
And not to range abroad to seek out Ruin:
Experience shows, his Purse shall soon grow light,
Whom Dice wastes in the day, Drabs in the night:
Let all avoid false Strumpets, Dice, and Drink;
For he that leaps in Mud, shall quickly sink.

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.p: Yonder is the man.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p:
I thank you.
How is it with you, sir? What on the ground?
Look up there is comfort towards you.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p:
Belike some charitable Friend has sent a Shilling,
What is your Business?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Liberty.

sp.speaker: Spend.
Long.
sp.p:
The able, and weal-minded Widow Raysby,
Whose hand is still upon the poor man's Box,
Hath in her Charity remembered you:
And being by your Master seconded,
Hath taken order with your Creditors
For day, and payment; and freely from her Purse,
By me her Deputy, she hath discharged
All Duties in the House: Besides, to your necessities.
This is bequeathed, to furnish you with Clothes.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Speak you this seriously?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: It is not my practise to mock Misery.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p:
Be ever praised that Divinity,
That has to my oppressed state raised Friends:
still be his blessings poured upon their heads:
Your hand, I pray,
That have so faithfully performed their wills:
If ever my industry, joined with their loves,
Shall raise me to a competent estate,
Your name shall ever be to me a friend.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: In your good wishes, you requite me amply.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: All Fees, you say, are paid? there is for you love.

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.p: I thank you sir, and glad you are released.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p:
How Apparel makes a man respected; the very children
in the street do adore me: for if a Boy that is throwing
at his Jack-a-lent chance to hit me on the shins: Why I
say nothing but, Tu quoque, smile, and forgive the Child with
a beck of my hand, or some such like token: so by that
means, I do seldom go without broken shins.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p:
The blessings of your Mistress fall upon you,
And may the heat and spirit of Her lip,
Endue her with matter above her understanding,
That she may only live to admire you, or as the Italian says,
Que que dell fogo Ginni Coxcombie.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p:
I do wonder what language he speaks.
Do you hear my friend, are not you a Conjurer?

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p:
I am sir, a perfect Traveller, that have trampled over
The face of this universe. and can speak Greek and
Latin as promptly, as my own natural Language:
I have composed a Book, wherein I have set down
All the Wonders of the world that I have seen,
And the whole scope of my Journeys, together with the
Miseries and lousy fortunes I have endured therein.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p:
O Lord Sir, are you the man; give me your hand:
How do ye: in good faith I think I have heard of you.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p:
No sir, you never heard of me, I set this day footing
Upon the Wharf, I came in with the last peal of Ordinance,
And dined this day in the Exchange amongst the Merchants.
But this is frivolous and from the matter: you do seem
To be one of our Genteel spirits that do affect Generosity:
Pleaseth you to be instituted in the nature, Garb, and habit,
Of the most exactest Nation in the world, the Italian:
Whose Language is sweetest, Clothes neatest, and behaviour
Most accomplished: I am one that have spent much money,
And time; which to me is more dear than money, in the
Observation of these things: and now I am come,
I will sit me down and rest, and make no doubt,
But by quality, to purchase and build, by professing this Art,
Or human Science (as I may term it,) to such Honourable
And Worshipful personages as mean to be peculiar.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p:
This fellow has his tongue at his fingers ends:
But hark you sir, is your Italian the finest Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p:
In the world Seignior, your Spaniard is a mere Bombard
to him: he will bounce indeed; but he will burst: But your
Italian is smooth and lofty, and his language is, Cozen germane
to the Latin.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Why then he has his Tu quoque in his salute?

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p:
Yes sir, for it is an Italian word as well as a Latin,
And enfolds a double sense: for one way spoken,
It includes a fine Gentleman like yourself;
And another way, it imports an Ass, like whom you will.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p:
I would my man Iaruis were here, for he understands
these things better than I. You will not serve?

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: Serve, no sir, I have talked with the great Sophy.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: I parry sir, what is the lowest price of being Italianated?

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p:
Sir, if it please you, I will stand to your bounty:
And mark me, I will set your fate like a Grand seignor's,
And you shall march a whole day, until you come opounctly
to your Mistress,
And not disrank one hair of your physiognomy.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p:
I would you would do it Sir, if you will stand to my
Bounty, I will pay you, as I am an Itatian tu quoque.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p:
Then sir, I will first disburden you of your Cloak,
You will be the nimbler to practise: Now sir, observe me,
Go you directly to the Lady to whom you devote yourself.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p:
You shall set a good stayed face upon the matter then.
Your Band is not to your Shirt, is it?

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: No sir, it is loose.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p:
It is the fitter for my purpose.
I will first remove your Hat, it has been the fashion (as I
have heard) in England, to wear your Hat thus in your eyes;
But it is gross, naught, inconvenient, and proclaims with a
loved voice; that he that brought it up first, stood in fear of
Sergeants. Your Italian is contrary, he doth advance his
Hat, and sets it thus.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Excellent well: I would you would set on my head so.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p:
Soft, I will first remove your Band, and set it out of the
reach of your eye; it must lie altogether backward: So, your
Band is well.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Is it as you would have it!

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p:
It is as I would wish; only sir, this I must condition
you of; in your affront or salute, never to move your Hat:
But here, here is your courtesy.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p:
Nay I warrant you, let me alone; if I perceive a thing
once, I will carry it away: Now pray sir, reach my Cloak.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: Never whilst you live, sir.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: No, what do your Italians wear no Cloaks?

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: Your Seigniors never: you feel I am unfurnished myself.

body.stage: Enter Sir Lyo. Will Rash, Geraldine, Widdow, Gartred, and Ioyce.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p:
Say so prethee keep it then. See, yonder is the company
that I look for; therefore if you will set my face of any
fashion, pray do it quickly?

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p:
You carry your face as well as ever an Italian in the
world, only enrich it with a Smile, and it is incomparable:
and thus much more, at your first appearance, you shall perhaps
strike your acquaintance into an ecstasy, or perhaps a laughter:
but it is ignorance in them, which will soon be overcome,
if you persevere.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p:
I will persevere, I warrant thee; only do thou stand
aloof and be not seen, because I would have them think I
fetched it out of my own practise.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: Do not you fear, I will not be seen, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Lyo.
sp.p:
Now Widow, you are welcome to my house,
And to your own house too; so you may call it:
For what is mine, is yours: you may command here,
As at home, and be as soon obeyed.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: May I deserve this kindness of you, sir?

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Save you Gent. I salute you after the Italian fashion.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: How, the Italian fashion? Zounds, he has dressed him rarely

sp.speaker: Lyo.
sp.p: My son Bubble, I take it?

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p:
The nether part of him I think is he,
But what the upper part is, I know not.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p:
By my troth he is a rare fellow, he said true:
They are all in an ecstasy.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: I think he is mad?

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p:
Nay that cannot be; for they say, they that are mad,
lose their wits: and I am sure he had none to lose.

sp.speaker: Lyo.
sp.p:
How now son Bubble, how come you thus attired?
What, do you mean to make yourself a laughing stock, ha?

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Vm; Ignorance, ignorance.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p:
For the love of laughter, look yonder,
Another Hearing in the same pickle.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: The tother Hobby-horse I perceive is not forgotten.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p:
Who has made him such a Coxcomb trow?
An Italian tu quoque.

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p: I salute you according to the Italian fashion.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p:
Puh, the Italian fashion? the tatterdemalion fashion
he means.

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p: Save you sweet bloods, save you.

sp.speaker: Lyo.
sp.p: Why but what jig is this?

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p:
Nay if I know father, would I were hanged,
I am even as Innocent as the Child new born.

sp.speaker: Lyo.
sp.p: Aye but son Bubble, where did you two buy your Felts?

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p:
Felts? By this light, mine is a good Beaver:
It cost me three pound this morning upon trust.

sp.speaker: Lyo.
sp.p:
Nay, I think you had it upon trust: for no man that
has any shame in him, would take money for it: behold Sir.

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Lyo.
sp.p: Nay never do you laugh, for you are in the same blocke.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Is this the Italian fashion?

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p:
No, it is the Fool's fashion:
And we two are the first that follow it.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p:
Et tu quoque; are we both cozened:
Then let us show ourselves brothers in adversity, and embrace.

sp.speaker: Lyo.
sp.p: What was he that cheated you?

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Marry sir, he was a Knave that cheated me.

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p: And I think he was no honest man, that cheated me,

sp.speaker: Lyo.
sp.p: Do you know him again, if you see him?

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p:
Yes I know him again, if I see him:
But I do not know how I should come to see him.
O Jaruis, Iaruis, do you see us two, Iaruis?

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: Yes sir, very well.

sp.speaker: Bub.
Sta.
sp.p: Why sir, you have not lost your Cloak and Hat.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p:
Iaruis you lie, I have lost my Cloak and Hat:
And therefore you must use your credit for another.

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p:
I think my old Cloak and Hat, must be glad to
serve me till next quarter day.

sp.speaker: Lyo.
sp.p:
Come, take no came for Cloaks, I will furnish you:
Tonight you lodge with me, tomorrow morn
Before the Sun be up, prepare for Church,
The Widow and I have so concluded on it:
The Wenches understand not yet so much,
Nor shall not, until bedtime: then will they,
Not sleep a wink all night, for very joy.

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p:
And I will promise the next night,
They shall not sleep for joy neither.

sp.speaker: Lyo.
sp.p:
O Master Geraldine, I saw you not before:
Your Father now is come to town, I hear?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Lyo.
sp.p:
Were not my business earnest, I would see him:
But pray entreat him break an hour's sleep
Tomorrow morn, to accompany me to Church;
And come yourself I pray along with him.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Sir, I thank you.

sp.speaker: Lyo.
sp.p:
But look, here comes one,
That has but lately shook off his Shackles.
How now sirrah, wherefore come you?

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p:
I come to crave a pardon sir, of you,
And with hearty and zealous thanks
Unto this worthy Lady, that hath given me
More than I ever could hope for: Liberty.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p:
Be thankful unto Heaven, and your Master:
Nor let your heart grow bigger than your Purse,
But live within a limit, lest you burst out
To Riot, and to Misery again:
For then it would lose the benefit I meant it.

sp.speaker: Lyo.
sp.p:
O you do graciously, it is good advice:
Let it take root sirrah, let it take root.
But come Widow come, and see your Chamber;
Nay your company too, for I must speak with you.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: It is bound unto you Sir.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p:
And I have to talk with you too, Mistress Ioyce:
Pray a word.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p: What would you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p:
Pray let me see your hand: the line of your Maidenhead
is out. Now for your Finger; upon which Finger will
you wear your wedding Ring?

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p: Upon no Finger.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p:
Then I perceive you mean to wear it on your thumb.
Well, the time is come sweet Ioyce, the time is come.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p: What to do, sir?

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p:
For me to tickle thy Tu quoque; to do the act of our
forefathers: therefore prepare, provide,
Tomorrow morn to meet me as my Bride.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p: I will meet thee like a Ghost first.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: How now, what matter have you fished out of that fool?

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p:
Matter as poisoning as Corruption,
That will without some Antidote strike home
Like blue Infection to the very heart.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: As how, for Gods sake?

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p: Tomorrow is the appointed Wedding day.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: The day of doom it is?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: It would be a dismal day indeed to some of us.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p:
Sir, I do know you love me; and the time
Will not be dallied with: be what you seem,
Or not the same: I am your Wife, your Mistress,
Or your Servant; indeed what you will make me:
Let us no longer wrangle with our Wits,
Or dally with our Fortunes; lead me hence,
And carry me into a Wilderness:
I will fast with you, rather than feast with him.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p:
What can be welcomer unto these arms?
Not my estate recovered, is more sweet,
Nor strikes more joy in me, than does your love.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p:
Will you both kiss then upon the bargain,
Here is two couple on you; God give you joy,
I wish well to you, and I see it is all the good that I can do you:
And so to your shifts I leave you.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.p: Nay Brother, you will not leave us thus, I hope.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p:
Why what would you have me do, you mean to run
away together, would you have me run with you, and so lose
my Inheritance: no, trudge, trudge with your backs to me,
and your bellies to them: away.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p:
Nay I prithee be not thus unseasonable:
Without thee we are nothing.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p:
By my troth, and I think so too: you love one another
in the way of Matrimony, do you not?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: What else man?

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p:
What else man? why it is a question to be asked;
For I can assure you, there is an other kind of love:
But come follow me, I must be your good Angel still:
It is in this brain how to prevent my Father, and his brace
Of Beagles: you shall none of you be bid tonight:
Follow but my direction, if I bring you not,
To have and to hold, for better for worse, let me be held an
Eunuch in wit, and one that was never Father to a good Feast.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: We will be instructed by you.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p:
Well, if you be, it will be your own another day.
Come follow me.

body.stage: Spendall meetes them, and they looke strugely vpon him, and Exit.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p:
How ruthless men are to adversity,
My acquaintance scarce will know me, when we meet
They cannot stay to talk, they must be gone;
And shake me by the hand as if I burnt them:
A man must trust unto himself, I see;
For if he once but halt in his estate,
Friendship will prove but broken Crutches to him:
Well, I will lean to none of them, but stand
Free of myself: and if I had a spirit
Daring to act what I am prompted to,
I must thrust out into the world again,
Full blossomed with a sweet and golden Spring:
It was an argument of love in her
To fetch me out of Prison, and this night,
She clasped my hand in hers, as who should say,
Thou art my Purchase, and I hold thee thus:
The worst is but repulse, if I attempt it:
I am resolved, my Genius whispers to me
Go on and win her, thou art young and active;
Which she is apt to catch at, for there is naught
That is more unsteadfast, than a woman's thought.

body.stage: Enter Sir Lyo, Will Rash, Scatter-good, Bubble, Widdow, Gartred, Ioyce, Phillis, and Seruant.

sp.speaker: Lyo.
sp.p:
Here is ill lodging Widow: but you must know,
If we had better, we could afford it you.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: The lodging Sir, might serve better Guests.

sp.speaker: Lyo.
sp.p:
Not better, Widow, nor yet welcomer:
But we will leave you to it, and the rest.
Phillis, pray let your Mistress want not anything,
Once more Good night, I will leave a kiss with you,
As earnest of a better Gift tomorrow.
Sirrah, a Light.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Good rest to all.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Et tu quoque, forsooth.

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p:
God give you good-night, forsooth,
And send you an early resurrection.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: God-night to both.

sp.speaker: Lyo.
sp.p:
Come, come away, each Bird unto his nest,
Tomorrow night is a time of little rest.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p:
Here untie: soft, let it alone,
I have no disposition to sleep yet:
Give me a Book, and leave me for a while,
Some half hour hence, look into me.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: I shall forsooth.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: How now, what makes this bold intrusion?

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Pardon me Lady, I have business to you.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p:
Business, from whom, is it of such importance
That it craves present hearing?

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: It does.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Then speak it, and be brief.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p:
Nay gentle Widow, be more pliant to me.
My suite is soft and courteous: full of love.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Of love?

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Of love.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p:
Why sure the man is mad? bethink thyself,
Thou hast forgot thy errand?

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p:
I have indeed, fair Lady; for my errand
Should first have been delivered on your lips.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p:
Why thou impudent fellow, unthrift of shame,
As well as of thy pursue; What has moved thee
To prosecute thy ruin? hath my bounty,
For which thy Master was an orator,
Importune thee to pay me with abuse?
Sirrah retire, or I will to your shame,
With clamours raise the house, and make your Master
For this attempt, return you to the Dungeon,
From whence you came.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p:
Nay then I must be desperate:
Widow, hold your Clapdish, fasten your Tongue
Unto your Roof, and do not dare to call,
But give me audience, with fear and silence:
Come kiss me: No?
This Dagger has a point, do you see it?
And be unto my suite obedient,
Or you shall feel it too:
For I will rather totter, hang in clean Linen,
Than live to scrub it out in lousy Linings.
Go to, kiss: You will? why so: Again: the third time?
Good, it is a sufficient Charm: Now hear me,
You are rich in Money, Lands, and Lordships,
Manors, and fair Possessions, and I have not so much
As one poor Copy-hold to thrust my head in.
Why should you not then have compassion
upon a reasonable hand some fellow,
That has both youth and livelihood upon him;
And can at midnight quicken and refresh
Pleasures decayed in you? You want Children,
And I am strong, lusty, and have a back
Like Hercules, able to get them
Without the help of Muscadine and Eggs:
And will you then, that have enough,
Take to your Bed a bundle of diseases,
Wrapped up in threescore years, to lie a hawking,
Spitting, and coughing backwards and forwards
That you shall not sleep; but thrusting forth
Your face out of the Bed, be glad to draw
The Curtains, such a steam shall reek
Out of this dunghill. Now what say yon?
Shall we without further wrangling clap it up,
And go to Bed together?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Will you hear me?

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p:
Yes with all my heart,
So the first word may be, Untruss your Points.
Zounds one knocks: do not stir I charge you,
Nor speak, but what I bid you:
For by these Lips, which now in love I kiss,
If you but struggle, or but raise your voice,
My arm shall rise with it, and strike you dead.
Go to, come on with me, and ask who is there?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: It is my Maid.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: No matter, do as I bid you: say, Who is there?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Who is there?

sp.speaker: Phillis
sp.p: It is I, forsooth.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p:
If it be you, forsooth, then pray stay.
Till I shall call; upon you.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p:
If it be you forsooth, then pray you stay,
Till I shall call upon you.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p:
Very well, why now I see
Thou wilt prove an obedient wise, come, let us undress.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Will you put up your naked weapon sir?

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p:
You shall pardon me (Widow) I must have you
grant first.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: You will not put it up.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Not till I have some token of your love.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p:
If this may be a testimony take it.
By all my hopes I love thee, thou art worthy
Of the best widow living, thou takest the course;
And those that will win widows must do thus.

sp.speaker: Spen.
sp.p:
Nay, I knew what I did, when I came with my naked
weapon in my hand; but come, unlace.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p:
Nay my dear love, know that I will not yield
My body unto lust, until the Priest
Shall join us in Hymens sacred nuptial rites.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p:
Then set your hand to this, nay it is a contract
Strong and sufficient, and will hold in Law,
Here, here is pen and ink, you see I come provided.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Give me the pen.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p:
Why here is some comfort,
Yet write your name fair I pray,
And at large; why now it is very well,
Now widow you may admit your Maid,
For in the next room I will go fetch a nap.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p:
Thou shalt not leave me so, come prithee sit,
We will talk a while, for thou hast made my heart
Dance in my bosom I receive such joy.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Thou art a good wench i'faith, come kiss upon it.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p:
But will you be a loving husband to me,
Avoid all naughty company, and be true
To me, and to my bed?

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: As true to thee, as Steel to Adamant.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p:
I will bind you to your word, see that you be,
Or I will conceal my bags, I have kinsfolks,
To whom I will make it over, you shall not have a penny.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p:
Push, prithee do not doubt me,
How now, what means this?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p:
It means my vengeance; nay sir, you are fast;
Nor do not dare to struggle, I have liberty,
Both of my tongue and feet, I will call my maid:
Phillis come in, and help to triumph,
Over this bold Intruder, wonder not wench,
But go unto him, and ransack all his pockets,
And take from thence a Contract which he forced
From my unwilling fingers.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Is this according to your oath.

sp.speaker: Phillis
sp.p: Come sir, I must search you.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p:
I prithee do.
And when thou takest that from me, take my life too.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Hast thou it girl?

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: I have a paper here.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p:
It is the same, give it me, look you sir,
Thus your new fancied hopes I tear asunder:
Poor wretched man, thou hast had a golden dream,
Which gilded over thy calamity:
But being awake thou findest it ill laid on,
For with one finger I have wiped it off:
Go fetch me hither the Casket that contains
My choicest Jewels, and spread them here before him;
Look you sir:
Here is gold, pearl, rubies, sapphires, diamonds;
These would be goodly things for you to pawn,
Or revel with amongst your Courtesans,
Whilst I and mine did starve: why dost not curse,
And utter all the mischiefs of thy heart,
Which I know swells within thee, power it out,
And let me hear thy fury.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p:
Never, never:
When ever my tongue shall speak but well of thee,
It proves no faithful servant to my heart.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p:
False traitor to thy master, and to me,
Thou liest, there is no such thing within thee.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p:
May I be burned to ugliness, to that
Which you and all men hate, but I speak truth.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p:
May I be turned a monster, and the shame
Of all my Sex, - and if I not believe thee,
Take me unto thee, these, and all that is mine,
Were it thrice trebled, thou wert worthy all:
And do not blame this trial, cause it shows
I give myself unto thee, am not forced,
And with it alone, that never shall be divorced.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p:
I am glad it is come to this yet, by this light
Thou puttest me into a horrible fear:
But this is my excuse: know that my thoughts
Were not so desperate as my actions seemed,
For fore my dagger should have drawn one drop
Of thy chaste blood, it should have sluiced out mine:
And the cold point struck deep into my heart:
Nor better be my fate, if I shall move
To any other pleasure but thy love.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p:
It shall be in my Creed: but let us away,
For night with her black Steeds draws up the day.

body.stage: Enter Rash, Staines, Geraldine, Gartred, Ioyce, and a Boy with a Lanthorne.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p:
Softly Boy, softly, you think you are upon firm
ground, but it is dangerous; you will never make a good thief,
you rogue, till you learn to creep upon all four: if I do not
swear with going this pace: everything I see, methinks,
should be my father in his white beard.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p:
It is the property of that passion, for fear
Still shapes all things we see to that we fear.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p:
Well said Logic, sister, I pray lay hold of him,
For the man I see is able to give the Watch an answer, if they

should come upon him with Interrogatories: zownds we are
discovered, boy, come up close, and use the property of your
Lantern: what dumb show should this be?

sp.speaker: Geral.
sp.p: They take their way directly, intend nothing gainst us.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: Can you not discern who they are?

sp.speaker: Ioyce.
sp.p: One is Spendall.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p: The other is the Widow as I take it.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: It is true, and that is her maid before her.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p:
What a night of conspiracy is here, more villainy?
there is another goodly mutton going, my father is fleeced of
all, grief will give him a box i'faith, but it is no great matter,
I shall inherit the sooner, nay soft sir, you shall not pass so currant
with the matter, I will shake you a little: who goes there?

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Out with the Candle, who is it that asks the question?

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: One that has some reason for it.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p:
It should be, by the voice, young Rash.
Why we are honest folks.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: Pray where do you dwell? not in town I hope.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p:
Why we dwell, zownds where do we dwell?
I know not where.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p:
And you will be married you know not when, zownds
it were a Christian deed to stop thee in thy journey: hast thou
no more spirit in thee, but to let thy tongue betray thee. Suppose
I had been a Constable, you had been in a fine taking,
had you not!

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p:
But my still worthy friend,
Is there no worse face of ill bent towards me,
Then that thou merrily puttest on.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p:
Yes, here is four or five faces more, but never an ill
one, though never an excellent good one, Boy, up with your
lantern of light, and show him his associates, all running away
with the flesh as thou art, go yoke together, you may
be oxen one day, and draw all together in a plough, go march
together, the Parson stays for you, pay him royally, come,
give me the Lantern, for you have light sufficient, for night
has put off his black Cap, and salutes the morn, now farewell
my little children of Cupid, that walk by two and two
as if you went a feasting: let me hear no more words, but be
gone.

sp.speaker: Spend. & Sta.
sp.p: Farewell.

sp.speaker: Gart. & Ioyce
sp.p: Farewell brother.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p:
Aye, you may cry farewell, but if my father should know
of my villainy, how should I fare then? but all is one, I have done
my sisters good, my friends good, and myself good, and a general
good is always to be respected before a particular, there is
eight score pounds a year saved, by the conveyance of this
widow, I hear footsteps, now darkness take me into thy
arms, and deliver me from discovery.

sp.speaker: Lyonell.
sp.p:
Lord, lord, what a careless world is this, neither
Bride nor Bridegroom ready, time to go to Church, and not
a man unroosted, this age has not seen a young Gallant rise
with a candle, we live drowned in feather-beds, and dream of
no other felicity: this was not the life when I was a young man,
what makes us so weak as we are now? a feather-bed: what
so unapt for exercise? a feather-bed: what breeds such pains
and aches in our bones? why a feather-bed or a wench, or at
least a wench in a feather-bed: is it not a shame, that an old
man as I am should be up first, and in a wedding day, I think
in my conscience there is more metal in lads of three score,
than in boys of one and twenty.
Why Basket hilt.

sp.speaker: Bask.
sp.p: Here sir.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: Shall I not be trussed today?

sp.speaker: Bask.
sp.p: Yes sir, but I went for water.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: Is Will Rash up yet?

sp.speaker: Basket.
sp.p:
I think not sir, for I heard nobody stirring in the
house.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p:
Knock sirrah at his chamber,
The house might be plucked down and builded again
Before he would wake with the noise.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: Who is that keeps such a knocking, are you mad?

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p:
Rather thou art drunk, thou lazy slouch,
That makest thy bed thy grave, and in it buriest
All thy youth and vigour; up for shame.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: Why it is not two a clock yet.

sp.speaker: Lyo.
sp.p:
Out sluggish knave it is nearer unto five,
The whole house has out-slept themselves, as if they had drunk
wild poppy: Sirrah, go you and raise the maids, and let them
call upon their mistresses.

sp.speaker: Bask.
sp.p: Well sir, I shall.

sp.speaker: Scatt.
sp.p:
Did I eat any Lettuce to supper last night, that I am
so sleepy, I think it be day light, brother Bubble.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: What sayst thou brother? heigh ho!

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p:
Fie, fie, not ready yet? what sluggishness
Hath seized upon you? why thine eyes are close still.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p:
As fast as a Kentish oyster, surely I was begotten in a
Plumb-tree,
I have such a deal of gum about mine eyes.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p:
Lord how you stand! I am ashamed to see
The Sun should be a witness of your sloth,
Now sir, your haste.

sp.speaker: Bask.
sp.p:
Marry sir, there are guests coming to accompany
you to church.

sp.speaker: Ly.
sp.p:
Why this is excellent, men whom it not concerns
Are more respective than we that are main Actors.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p:
Father Rash, be not so outrageous, we will go in and
buckle ourselves, all in good time, how now! what is this about
my shins?

sp.speaker: Scatt.
sp.p:
Methought our shanks were not fellows, we have
metamorphosed our stockings for want of splendour.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Pray what is that Splendour?

sp.speaker: Scatt.
sp.p: Why it is the Latin word for a Christmas candle

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p:
O Gentlemen, you love, you honour me, welcome,
welcome good Master Geraldine, you have taken pains
To accompany an undeserving friend.

sp.speaker: Old Ger.
sp.p:
You put us to a needless labour sir,
To run and wind about for circumstance,
When the plaint word, I thank you, would have served.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p:
How now wench, are the females ready yet?
The time comes on upon us, and we run backward:
We are so untoward in our business,
We think not what we have to do, nor what we do.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p:
I know not sir whether they know what to do, but
I am sure they have been at Church well-nigh an hour, they
were afraid you had got the start of them, which made them
make such haste.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p:
Is it possible, what think you Gentlemen?
Are not these wenches forward? is there not virtue in a man
can make young Virgins leave their beds so soon.
But is the widow gone along with them?

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: Yes sir, why she was the ring-leader.

body.stage: Enter Spend Sta. Geraldine, Widdow, Gartred, and Ioyce.

sp.speaker: Lyo.
sp.p:
I thought as much, for she knows what belongs to it,
Come Gentlemen, methinks it is sport to see
Young wenches run to church before their husbands:
Faith we shall make them blush for this ere night:
A sirrah, are you come? why that is well said;
I marveled indeed that all things were so quiet,
Which made me think they had not unwrapped their sheet:
And then were they at Church I hold my life:
Maids think it long until each be made a wise.
Hast thou my cloak knave? well said, put it on,
We will after them; let me go hasten both,
Both the Bridegrooms forward, we will walk a little
Softly on afore: but see, see, if they be not come
To fetch us now, we come. we come,
Bid them return, and save themselves this labour.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p: Now have I a quartan ague upon me.

sp.speaker: Lyonell.
sp.p:
Why how now! why come you from Church to
kneel thus publicly, what is the matter?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: We kneel sir for your blessing.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: How, my blessing! Master Geraldine, is not that your son?

sp.speaker: Old Ger.
sp.p: Yes sir, and that I take it is your daughter.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p:
I suspect knavery, what are you?
Why do you kneel hand in hand with her?

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: For a fatherly blessing too sir.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p:
Hoy day! it is palpable, I am gulled, and my son
Scatter-good and Bubble fooled, you are married?

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Yes sir, we are married.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: More villainy! everything goes the wrong way.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: We shall go the right way anon, I hope.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p:
Yes marry shall you, you shall even to the Counter
again, and that is the right way for you.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p:
O you are wrong,
The prison that shall hold him are these arms.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p:
I do fear that I shall turn stinkard, I do smell such
a matter: you are married then?

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p: Ecce signum, here is the wedding Ring to affirm it.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p:
I believe the knave has drunk Ipocras,
He is so pleasant.

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p: God morrow Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p:
Tu quoque to all: what, shall we go to Church?
Come, I long to be about this gear.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p:
Do you hear me, will you two go sleep again?
take out the tother nap, for you are both made Coxcombs,
and so am I.

sp.speaker: Scatt.
sp.p: How, Coxcombs!

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: Yea Coxcombs.

sp.speaker: Scatt.
sp.p: Father, that word Coxcomb goes against my stomach.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p:
And against mine, a man might have digested a Woodcock
better.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p:
You two come now to go to church to be married,
And they two come from Church, and are married.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: How, married! I would see that man durst marry her.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Why sir, what would you do?

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Why sir I would forbid the banes.

sp.speaker: Scatt.
sp.p: And so would I.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p:
Do you know that youth in Satin, he is the penner
that belongs to that Inkhorn.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: How, let me see, are not you my man Geruase?

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: And have you married her?

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: And do you think you have used me well?

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p:
O intolerable rascal! I will presently be made a Justice
of Peace, and have thee whipped, go fetch a Constable.

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p:
Come, you are a flourishing Ass; Sergeant take him to
thee, he has had a long time of his pageantry.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p:
Sirrah let him go, I will be his bail, for all debts which
come against him.

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p:
Reverend sir, to whom I owe the duty of a son,
Which I shall ever pay in my obedience:
Know that which made him gracious in your eyes,
And gilded over his imperfections,
Is wasted and consumed even like ice,
Which by the vehemence of heat dissolves,
And glides to many rivers, so his wealth,
That felt a prodigal hand, hot in expense,
Melted within his gripe, and from his coffers,
Ran like a violent stream to other men's,
What was my own, I catched at.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: Have you your mortgage in?

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p:
Stand up, the matter is well amended,
Master Geraldine, you give sufferance to this match.

sp.speaker: Old Ger.
sp.p:
Yes marry do I sir, for since they love,
I will not have the crime lie on my head,
To divide man and wife.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: Why you say well, my blessing fail upon you,

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: And upon us that love sir Lyonnell.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p:
By my troth since thou hast taken the young knave,
God give thee joy of him, and may he prove
A wiser man than his Master.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: Sergeant, why dost not carry him to prison?

sp.speaker: Serg.
sp.p: Sir Lyonell Rash will bail him.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p:
I bail him knave! wherefore should I bail him?
No, carry him away, I will relieve no prodigals.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p:
Good sir Lyonell, I beseech you sir, Gentlemen, I pray
make a purse for me.

sp.speaker: Serg.
sp.p: Come sir, come, are you begging?

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p:
Why that does you no harm Geruase, master I should
say; some compassion.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p:
Sergeants, come back with him, look sir, here is
your livery,
If you can put off all your former pride,
And put on this with that humility
That you first wore it, I will pay your debts,
Free you of all encumbrances,
And take you again into my service.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p:
Tenter-hook let me go, I will take his worships
offer without wages, rather than come into your clutches again;
a man in a blue coat may have some colour for his
knavery, in the Counter he can have none.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: But now Master. Scatter-good, what say you to this?

sp.speaker: Scat.
sp.p:
Marry I say it is scarce honest dealing for any man to
Cony-catch another man's wife, I protest we will not put it up.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: No, which we?

sp.speaker: Scatt.
sp.p: Why Gartred and I.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p: Gartred, why she will put it up.

sp.speaker: Scatt.
sp.p: Will she?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Aye that she will, and so must you.

sp.speaker: Scatt.
sp.p: Must I?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Yes that you must.

sp.speaker: Scatt.
sp.p:
Well, if I must, I must; but I protest I would not:
But that I must: So vale, vale: Et tu quoque.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p:
Why that is well said,
Then I perceive we shall wind up all wrong:
Come Gentlemen, and all our other guests:
Let our well-tempered bloods taste Bacchus feasts,
But let us know first how these sports delight,
And to these Gentlemen each bid good night.

sp.speaker: Rash.
sp.p:
Gentles, I hope, that well my labour ends,
All that I did was but to please my friends.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p:
A kind enamouret I did strive to prove,
But now I leave that, and pursue your love.

sp.speaker: Gart.
sp.p:
My part I have performed with the rest,
And though I have not, yet I would do best.

sp.speaker: Sta.
sp.p:
That I have cheated through the Play, it is true,
But yet I hope, I have not cheated you.

sp.speaker: Ioyce.
sp.p:
If with my clamours I have done you wrong,
Ever hereafter I will hold my tongue.

sp.speaker: Spend.
sp.p:
If through my riot I have offensive been,
Henceforth I will play the civil Citizen.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p:
Faith all that I say, is, how ever it hap,
Widows like Maids sometimes may catch a clap.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p:
To mirth and laughter henceforth I will provoke ye,
If you but please to like of Greenes Tu quoque.
